respStmt.name: Transcription: Peter Robinson, Barbara Bordalejo and members of the Canterbury Tales Project at Oxford and Sheffield (1992-1998), De Montfort University, Leicester (1998-2005), Birmingham (2005-2010), Saskatoon (2010-2014), Virginia Tech, New York University, University of Murcia, Adam Mickiewicz University (Poznan) and Brigham Young University.

Oxford transcription team, 1992-1998: Peter Robinson, Elizabeth Solopova, Lorna Stevenson, with contributions from James McCabe, Hubert Stadler, Cathy Swires, Paul and Maureen Watry, Laura Wright, Diana Wyatt and Simon Horobin
Sheffield transcription team, 1992-1998, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson and Simon Horobin
De Montfort transcription team, 1998-2005: Peter Robinson, Barbara Bordalejo, Orietta Da Rold, Gavin Cole, Pip Willcox, Jennifer Marshall, Takako Kato, Jacob Thaisen, Nicole Green
University of Saskatchewan team, 2010-2013: Peter Robinson and Barbara Bordalejo
Virgina Tech team, led by Daniel W. Mosser
New York University team, led by David Hoover and Martha Rust, 2003-2006.

Brigham Young University transcription team, 1995-2006, led by Paul Thomas: Sara Black, Jessica Cox, Barbara Christiansen, Kerry Clift Spencer*, Heidi Elldredge, Leona Fisher Sankhla, Kela Flint*, Melissa Gallup, Shannon Harris, Rebecca Johnson, Mary Jorgensen, Darin Merrill*, Wesley Pack*, Jared Perkins, Jon Penny, Randall Rogers, Ryan Rowberry*, Sara Slack, Carie Soderquist Jackson*, Kat Southerland, Matt Tenney, Briton Wright, John Young. Asterisks after names denote those who supervised other transcribers.

Adam Mickiewicz University, Poznan, transcription team, 2007-2010: (names to be supplied), with support from Adam Mickiewicz University and the The Polish Ministry for Science and Higher Education, grant N104 045 32/4256.
Nila Vazquez Gonzalez, University of Murcia.
Institute of Book Studies and Textual Research of the University of Münster, Germany, c. 2000-2004,led by Gabriele Müller Oberhauser; transcribed by Ulrike Grassnick.

University of Sheffield, 1994-1999, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson, Orietta Da Rold and Simon Horobin. In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: (base) Vnto the straunge lordes / as was right
(base) ¶ Ne ther was holden / no disconfitynge
(base) But as a Iustes / or a tourneyinge
(base) For soothly / ther was no disconfiture
(base) For fallyng. nys nat but an auenture
(base) Ne to been had by force / vnto the stake
(base) Vnyolden / and with twenty knyghtes take
(base) O persone allone / withouten mo
(base) And haryed forth / by arm / foot / and to
(base) And eek his steede / dryuen forth with staues
(base) With footmen / bothe yemen and eek knaues
(base) It nas arretted hym / no vileynye
(base) Ther may no man / clepe it cowardye
(base) ¶ For which anoon / duc Theseus leet crye
(base) To stynten / al rancour and enuye
(base) The gre / as wel of oo syde as of oother
(base) And eyther syde ylyk as otheres brother
(base) And yaf hem yiftes / after hir degree
(base) And fully heeld a feeste / dayes three
(base) And conueyed / the kynges worthily
(base) Out of his toun / a iournee largely
(base) And hoom wente euery man / the righte way
(base) Ther was namoore / but fare wel haue good day
(base) Of this bataille / I wol namoore endite
(base) But speke of Palamon / and of Arcite
(base) Of Palamon wil I stynte alite
(base) ¶ Explicit secunda pars
(base) ¶ Incipit pars tercia and vltīma
(base) Swelleth the brest of Arcite / and the soore
(base) Encreeseth at his herte / moore and moore
(base) The clothered blood / for any lechecraft
(base) Corrupteth / and is in his bouk / ylaft
(base) That neyther veyne blood / ne ventusynge
(base) Ne drynke of herbes / may been his helpynge
(base) The vertu expulsyf / or animal
(base) Fro thilke vertu / clepyd natural
(base) Ne may the venym / voyden ne expelle
(base) The pipes of his longes / gan to swelle
(base) And euery lacerte / in his brest adown
(base) Is shent with venym and corrupcioun
(base) Hym gayneth neither / for to gete his lyf
(base) Vomyt vpward / ne downward laxatyf
(base) Al is to brosten / thilke regioun
(base) Nature / hath no dominacioun
(base) And certeinly / ther nature wol nat werche
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Fare wel Phisyk. go ber the man to cherche
(base) This al and som / that Arcita moot dye
(base) For which / he sendeth after Emelye
(base) And Palamon / that was his cosyn deere
(base) Thanne seyde he thus / as ye shal after heere
(base) ¶ Nat may the woful spirit in myn herte
(base) Declare a point of alle my sorwes smerte
(base) To yow my lady / that I loue moost
(base) But I byquethe / the seruice of my goost
(base) To yow / abouen euery creature
(base) Syn that my lyf / may no lenger dure
(base) Allas the wo / allas the peynes stronge
(base) That I for yow haue suffred / and so longe
(base) Allas the deeth / allas myn Emelye
(base) Allas / departyng of oure compaignye
(base) Allas myn hertes queene / allas my wif
(base) Myn hertes lady / endere of my lyf
(base) Myn hertys lady cawser of my tene
(base) What is this world / what axeth men to haue
(base) Now with his loue / now in his colde graue
(base) Allone / with outen any compaignye
(base) Fare wel / my sweete foo / myn Emelye
(base) And softe taak me / in youre Armes tweye
(base) For loue of god / and herkneth what I seye
(base) ¶ I haue heer / with my cosyn Palamoun
(base) Had stryf and rancour / many a day goun
(base) For loue of yow / and for my Ialousye
(base) And Iuppiter / so wys my soule gye
(base) To speken / of a seruaunt proprely
(base) With circumstaunces alle / trewely
(base) That is to seyn / trouthe / honour / knyghthede
(base) Wisdom / humblesse / estaat / and heigh kynrede
(base) Fredom / and al / that longeth to that art
(base) So Iuppiter / haue of my soule part
(base) As in this world / right now ne knowe I non
(base) So worthy to been loued / as Palamon
(base) That serueth yow / and wol doon al his lyf
(base) And if that euere / ye shal been a wyf
(base) Foryet nat Palamon / the gentil man
(base) And with that word / his speche faille gan
(base) For from his feet vp to his brest was come
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) The coold of deeth / that hadde hym ouercome
(base) And yet moore ouer / for in his armes two
(base) The vital strengthe / is lost and al ago
(base) Oonly the Intellect withoute moore
(base) That dwelled in his herte / syk and soore
(base) Gan faillen / whan the herte felte deeth
(base) Dusked hise eyen two / and fayled breeth
(base) But on his lady / yet caste he his eye
(base) His laste word / was mercy Emelye
(base) His spirit chaunged hous / and wente ther
(base) As I cam neuere / I kan nat tellen wher
(base) Therfore I stynte / I nam no dyuynystre
(base) Of soules / fynde I nat in this Registre
(base) Ne me ne lyst / thilke opynyons to telle
(base) Of hem / thogh that they writen wher they dwelle
(base) Arcite is coold / ther Mars his soule gye
(base) Now wol I speken / forth of Emelye
(base) That soroweth and cryeth I wyl not lye
(base) Now wepith Emelye ⁊and waylith Palamon
(base) ¶ Shrighte Emelye / and howleth Palamon
(base) And Theseus / his suster took anon
(base) Swownynge / and baar hire fro the corps away
(base) What helpeth it to tarien forth the day
(base) To tellen how she weep / bothe eue and morwe
(base) For in swich caas / wommen haue swich sorwe
(base) Whan that hir housbondes / been from hem ago
(base) That for the moore part they sorwen so
(base) Or ellis fallen / in swich a maladye
(base) That at the laste / certeinly they dye
(base) ¶ Infinite / been the sorwes and the teerys
(base) Of olde folk. and folk of tendre yeerys
(base) In al the town / for the deeth of this Theban
(base) As þat þ̉er/re was for deþ of þis Theban
(base) For hym ther wepeth bothe child a man
(base) For sorwe of him þer weepeþ boþe child and man
(base) So greet wepyng was ther noon certayn
(base) Whan Ector was broght al fressh yslayn
(base) To Troye / allas the pitee that was ther
(base) Cracchynge of chekes / rentyng eek of heer
(base) Why woldest thow be deed / thise wommen crye
(base) And haddest gold ynow / and Emelye
(base) ¶ No man / myghte gladen Theseus
(base) Sauyng his olde fader Egeus
(base) That knew / this worldes transmutacioun
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) As he hadde seyn it chaungen / bothe vp and down
(base) Ioye after wo / and wo after gladnesse
(base) And shewed hem / ensample and lyknesse
(base) ¶ Right as ther deyed neuere man / quod he
(base) That he ne lyued in erthe / in som degree
(base) Right so / ther lyued neuere man he seyde
(base) In al this world / that som tyme he ne deyde
(base) This world / nys but a thurghfare / ful of wo
(base) And we been pilgrymes / passynge to and fro
(base) Deeth is an ende / of euery worldly soore
(base) And oueral this / yet seyde he muchel moore
(base) To this effect ful wysly / to enhorte
(base) The peple / that they sholde hem reconforte
(base) ¶ Duc Theseus / withal his bisy cure
(base) Caste now / wher that the sepulture
(base) Of goode Arcite / may best ymaked be
(base) And eek moost honurable / in his degree
(base) And at the laste / he took conclusioun
(base) That ther / as first Arcite and Palamoun
(base) Hadden for loue / the bataille hem bitwene
(base) That in the selue groue / swoote and grene
(base) Ther as he hadde / hise amorouse desires
(base) His compleinte / and for loue his hote fyres
(base) He wolde make a fyr / in which the office
(base) Funeral / he myghte al acomplice
(base) And leet anoon comaunde / to hakke and hewe
(base) The okes olde / and leyen hem on a rewe
(base) In colpons / wel arrayed for to brenne
(base) Hise officers / with swifte feet they renne
(base) And ryde anoon / at his comandement
(base) And after this / Theseus hath ysent
(base) After a Beere / and it al ouerspradde
(base) With clooth of gold / the richeste / that he hadde
(base) And of the same suyte / he cladde Arcite
(base) Vpon his handes / his gloues white
(base) Eek on his heed / a coroune of laurer greene
(base) And in his hand / a swerd ful bright and keene
(base) He leyde hym bare the visage / on the beere
(base) Ther with he weep / that pitee was to heere
(base) And for the peple / sholde seen hym alle
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Whan it was day / he broghte hym to the halle
(base) That roreth / of the cryyng and the sown
(base) Tho cam / this woful Theban Palamoun
(base) With flotry berd / and ruggy asshy heerys
(base) In clothes blake / ydropped al with teerys
(base) And passyng othere / of wepyng Emelye
(base) The rufulleste / of al the compaignye
(base) In as muche / as the seruyce sholde be
(base) The moore noble / and ryche in his degree
(base) Duc Theseus / leet forth thre steedes brynge
(base) ¶ Duke theseus anon with oute lette
(base) Thre stedis white hath comaundid sette
(base) Vpon the whiche stedes trapped welle
(base) With cloth of golde ouer maile of stel
(base) That trapped weren in steel al gliterynge
(base) And couered with the armes / of daun Arcite
(base) Vpon thise steedes / grete and whyte
(base) Ther seten folk / of which oon baar his sheeld
(base) Another his spere / vpon his hondes heeld
(base) The thridde bar with hym / his bowe Turkeys
(base) Of brend gold / was the caas / and eek the harneys
(base) And ryden forth a paas / with sorweful cheere
(base) Toward the groue / as ye shul after heere
(base) The nobleste of the Grekys / that ther were
(base) Vpon hir shuldres / carieden the beere
(base) With slak paas / and eyen rede and weete
(base) Thurgh out the Citee / by the maister streete
(base) That sprad was al with blak and wonder hye
(base) Right of the same / is the strete ywrye
(base) Vpon the right hand / wente olde Egeus
(base) And on that oother syde / duc Theseus
(base) With vessels in hir hand / of gold ful fyn
(base) Al ful of hony / melk / and blood and wyn
(base) Eek Palamon / with ful greet compaignye
(base) And after that / cam woful Emelye
(base) With fyr in hande / as was that tyme the gyse
(base) To do the office / of funeral seruyse
(base) ¶ Heigh labour / and greet apparaillynge
(base) Was at the seruyce / and the fyr makynge
(base) That with his grene top / the heuene raughte
(base) And twenty fadme of brede / the armes straughte
(base) This is to seyn / the bowes / were so brode
(base) Of stree first ther was leyd many a lode
(base) But how the fyr was maked vpon highte
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Ne eek the names / how the trees highte
(base) As ook / Fyrre / Birch / Asp / Alder / holm / popler
(base) Wylow / Elm / Plane / Assh / Box / Chestayn / lynde / laurer
(base) Wilow / elme / plane hasil and whipultre
(base) Mapul / Thorn / Beech / hasyl / Ew / whippultree
(base) Mapil thorn / bech / aspe / box chesteyn lynd / laurer
(base) How they were feld / shal nat been told for me
(base) Ne how the goddes / ronnen vp and doun
(base) Desherited / of hir habitacioun
(base) In which they woneden / in reste and pees
(base) Nymphes / Fawnes / and Amadrides
(base) Ne how the beestes / and the bryddes alle
(base) Fledden / for fered / whan the wode was falle
(base) Ne how the ground / agast was of the lyght
(base) That was nat wont to seen the sonne bright
(base) Ne how the fyr / was couched first with stree
(base) And thanne with drye stikkes / clouen a three
(base) And thanne with grene wode / and spicerye
(base) And thanne with clooth of gold / and with perrye
(base) And thanne with cloth of golde and with perie
(base) And gerlandes hangynge / ful of many a flour
(base) The Mirre / thencens / withal so greet sauour
(base) Ne how Arcite / lay among al this
(base) Ne what richesse / aboute the body is
(base) Ne how that Emelye / as was the gyse
(base) Putte in the fyr / of funeral seruyse
(base) Ne how she swowned / whan men made the fyr
(base) Ne what she spak ne what was hir desir
(base) Ne what Iuels / men in the fyr caste
(base) Whan that the fyr was greet and brente faste
(base) Ne how somme caste hir sheeld / and somme hir spere
(base) And of hir vestimentz / whiche that they were
(base) And coppes fulle of Milk and wyn and blood
(base) In to the fyr / that brente as it were wood
(base) Ne how the Grekys / with An huge route
(base) Thries ryden / al the fyr aboute
(base) Vpon the left hand / with a loud shoutynge
(base) And thries / with hir speres claterynge
(base) And thryes wᵗith here sperys claterynge
(base) And thries / how the ladyes gonne crye
(base) And how that lad / was homward Emelye
(base) Ne how Arcite / is brent to Asshen colde
(base) Ne how that lychwake / was yholde
(base) Al thilke nyght ne how the grekys pleye
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) The wake pleyes / ne kepe I noght to seye
(base) Who wrastleth best naked / with oille enoynt
(base) Ne who that baar hym best in no disioynt
(base) I wol nat tellen al / how they goon
(base) Hoom til Atthenes / whan the pleye is doon
(base) But shortly to the poynt than wol I wende
(base) And maken / of my longe tale an ende
(base) ¶ By proces / and by lengthe of certeyn yerys
(base) Al stynt is / the moornynge and the terys
(base) Of Grekys / by oon general assent
(base) Thanne semed me / ther was a parlement
(base) At Atthenes / vpon a certeyn point and caas
(base) Among the whiche pointes / yspoken was
(base) To haue / with certeyn contrees alliance
(base) And haue fully / of Thebans obeisance
(base) For which / this noble Theseus anon
(base) Leet senden / after gentil Palamon
(base) Vnwist of hym / what was the cause and why
(base) But in his blake clothes / sorwefully
(base) He cam at his comandement / in hye
(base) Tho sente Theseus / for Emelye
(base) ¶ Whan they were set and hust was al the place
(base) And Theseus / abiden hath a space
(base) Er any word / cam from his wise brest /
(base) His eyen sette he / ther as was his lest
(base) And with a sad visage / he siked stille
(base) And after that right thus he seyde his wille
(base) ¶ The firste moeuere / of the cause aboue
(base) Whan he first made / the faire cheyne of loue
(base) Greet was theffect and heigh was his entente
(base) Wel wiste he why / and what ther of he mente
(base) For with that faire cheyne of loue he boond
(base) The fyr the Eyr / the water / and the loond
(base) In certeyn boundes / that they may nat flee
(base) That same Prince / and that moeuere quod he
(base) Hath stabliced / in this wrecched world adoun
(base) Certeine dayes / and duracioun
(base) To al / that is engendred / in this place
(base) Ouer the which day / they may nat pace
(base) Al mowe they yet / tho dayes abregge
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Ther nedeth / noon auctoritee to allegge
(base) For it is proued / by experience
(base) But that me list declaren my sentence
(base) Thanne may men wel / by this ordre discerne
(base) That thilke moeuere / stable is and eterne
(base) Wel may men knowe / but it be a fool
(base) That euery part. is diryued from his hool
(base) For nature / hath nat taken his bigynnyng
(base) Of no partie / or of cantel of a thyng
(base) But of a thyng. that parfit is and stable
(base) Descendynge so / til it be corrumpable
(base) And therfore / for his wise purueiaunce
(base) He hath / so wel biset his ordinaunce
(base) That specis of thynges / and progressions
(base) Shullen enduren / by successions
(base) And noght eterne / withouten any lye
(base) This maist thow vnderstonde / and seen at Iye
(base) ¶ Loo the ook / that hath so long a norisshynge
(base) Fro the tyme / that it first gynneth sprynge
(base) And hath so long a lyf / as ye may see
(base) Yet at the laste / wasted is the tree
(base) ¶ Considreth eek / how that the harde stoon
(base) Vnder oure foot on which we ryde and goon
(base) It wasteth / as it lyth by the weye
(base) The brode Ryuer / som tyme wexeth dreye
(base) The grete townes / se we wane and wende
(base) Thanne se ye / that al this thyng hath ende
(base) Of man and womman / se we wel also
(base) That nedeth / in oon of thise termes two
(base) This is to seyn / in youthe / or ellis age
(base) He moot be deed / the kyng as shal a page
(base) Som in his bed / som in the depe see
(base) Som in the large feeld / as ye may se
(base) Ther helpeth noght al gooth that ilke weye
(base) Thanne may I seyn / that al this thyng moot deye
(base) What maketh this but Iuppiter the kyng
(base) That is Prince / and cause of alle thyng
(base) Conuertyng al vnto his propre welle
(base) From which it is diryued sooth to telle
(base) And heer agayns / no creature on lyue

body.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.

div.l: (base) And For Gamelyn was yongest he sholde haue nought
(base) Alle the londe that ther was they dalten it in twoo
(base) And lete Gamelyn the yonge with outen londe goo
(base) And eche of hem saide til other ful loude
(base) His brothern mowe yeve hym londe when he good coude
(base) Whan they had delyd the londe at hire owne wille
(base) They come to the knyght ther he lay ful stille
(base) And tolde hym anoon how they hadde wrought
(base) And the knyght ther he lay lyked it right nought
(base) Than seyde the knyght be seint Martyn
(base) For al that ye haue don yet is the lond myn
(base) For goddes loue neighbours stondeth alle stille
(base) And I wole delen myn lond at myn owen wille
(base) Iohn myn Eldest sone shal haue plowes fyve
(base) That was my faders heritage while he was on lyve
(base) And my myddelest sone fyve plowes londe
(base) That I halpe to geten with my right honde
(base) And alle my other purchas of londes and ledes
(base) That I be quethe Gamelyn and alle my good stedes
(base) And I beseke yow good men that lawe kan of londe
(base) For Gamelynes loue that my quest stonde
(base) Thus dalt the knyght his londe by his day
(base) Right on his deth bedde sike ther he lay
(base) And sone afterwarde he lay stone stille
(base) And deide whan tyme come as it was cristis wille
(base) Anoon as he was deed and vnder gras graue
(base) Sone the eldere brothere bygiled the yonge knaue
(base) He toke into his hoond his londe and his lede
(base) And Gamelyn hym silfe to clothe and to fede
(base) He clothed hym and fedde hym wel and eke wroth
(base) And lete his londes forfare and his houses both
(base) His parkes and his wodes and did nothyng wel
(base) And sithen he hit aboughte in his faire fel
(base) So longe was Gamelyn in his brothers halle
(base) For the strengest of good wille thei doutide hym alle
(base) Ther was noon ther Inne noỷer/re yonge ne olde
(base) That wolde wrath Gamelyn were he neuer so bolde
(base) Gamelyn stood on a day in his brotheres yerde
(base) And bygan with his honde to handelyn his berde
(base) He thought on his londes that layn vnsawe
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And his faire Okes that doun were drawe
(base) His Park were broken and his dere reued
(base) Of alle his good stedes noon was hym byleued
(base) Hise houses were vnhelyd and fulle Ille dight
(base) Thoo thought Gamelyn it went nought a right
(base) Aftirward cam his brother walkyng thare
(base) And saide to Gamelyn is our mete yare
(base) Tho Gamelyn wrathed hym and swore by goddes boke
(base) Thow shalt goo bake thy selfe I wil not be thy coke

div.l: WHan eended was the tale of mellibe .
And of prudence and of hire benignite .
Oure oost saide as I am feithful man .
Ane be þe precious corpus madryan .
I hadde leuere thanne a barell aale .
Þat good leef my wyf hadde herd this tale .
For sche ne is no thyng of swich pacience .
As was this Mellibeus wyf prudence .
Be godis bones whanne I bete my knaues .
Sche bryngeth me þe greete clubbed staues .
And cryeth slee þe dogges euerichon .
And breke bothe bak and boon .
And if that ony neygheboure of myne .
Wile not in chirche to my wyf enclyne .
Or be soo hardy to hire do trespace .
Whanne sche cometh hoom sche rumpeth in my face .
And cryeth false coward wreke thy wyf .
Be corpus bonys I wile haue thy knyf .
And thou schalt haue my dystaff and goo spynne .
Fro day to nyght ryght thys sche wile begynne .
Allas sche sayth þat euere I was schape .
To wedden a melksop or a coward ape
Þat wile be ouirled with euery wyght .
Thou darst not stonde be thi wyf aryght .
Þis is my lyf but if that I wolde fyght
And out at the dore anoon I mote me dyght
Or elles I am lost but if that I .
Be lyk a wilde leoun fool hardy .
I woot weel sche wile doo me slee som day .
Some neyghebore and thanne go my way .
For I am ꝑper/parillous with knyf on honde .
All be it that I say hire nought withstonde .
For sche is bigge in armes be my feyth .
Þat schall he fynde that hire mysdooth or seyth .
But leet vs passe awey fro this matere .
My lord sire monk he sayth be mery of cheere .
For yee shule telle a tale trewely .
Loo Rouchestre stont heere faste by .
Ryde foorth myn owne lord breke not oure game .
But be my trouthe I knowe not yoᵘur name .
Whethir I schall calle yow my Lord doun Ion .
Or daun thomas or daun Albon .
Or of what hous be yee be yoᵘur fadir kyn .
I voute to god thou hast a full fayr skyn .
It is a gentil pasture there thou goost .
Thou art not lik a penaunt or a gost .
Vpon my feyth thou art som officere
Som worthi sexteyn or some celerere .
For be my fadir soule as to my dome
Thou art a maistir whanne thou art at home .
No poore cloistrer ne no poore nouis .
But gouernour wily and wys .
And therwith all of brawnes and of bones .
A weel farynge ꝑper/parsone for þe nones .
I preye to god yeue hym confusioun .
Þat first þe broughte in to religioun .
Thou woldest han been a tredfull aryght .
Haddest thou as greet leeue as thou hast myght .
To ꝑper/parfoormen al thi lust in engendrure .
Thou haddest be geten manye a creature .
Allas why werest thou soo wyde a cope .
God yeue me sorewe and I weere a pope .
Nought oonly thou but euery myghti man .
Though he weere schoren heeyghe vppon his pan .
Schulde haue a wyf for all this world is lorn .
Religioun hath taken vp all the corn .
Of tredyng and wee borell men be shrympes .
Of feeble trees þere cometh wrecched ympes .
Þis maketh that oure eyres be soo sclendre .
And feeble that thei may not weel engendre .
Þis maketh þat oure wyues wilen assay .
Religious folk for thei may bettere pay .
Of venus payment thanne mowe we .
God woot no lusshebornes paye yee
But beeth not wroth my lord though that I pleye
Full often in game a sooth I haue herd seye
Þis worthi monk took al pacience .
And seyde I wile doo al my diligence .
As ferre as souneth in to honeste .
To telle yow a tale or two or thre .
And if yow list herkene hiderward
I wile yow seyn þe lif of seynt Edward
Or ellis tregedys first wile I telle .
Of whiche I haue an hundred in my selle .
Tregedye is for to telle a certeyn storie .
As oolde bookes maken memorie .
Of hem that stooden in greet prosꝑper/parite .
And is fallen out of heeygh degree .
In to myserie and eendeth wrecchedly .
And thei been vercefied comounly .
Of sixe foot whiche that men clepe examytron .
In prose eek been endited manye oon .
And eek in metre in manye a sondry wyse .
Loo this oughte yow I nowgh suffice .
Now herkeneth if yow list for to heere .
But first I yow beseeche in this mateere .
Thought I be ordred telle nought these thynges .
Be it of popes emꝑper/parouris or kyngis .
And aftir here ages as men wryten fynde .
But telle hem somme before somme behynde .
As it cometh now to my remembraunce .
Haue me excused of myn ignorance .
Here endyth þe ꝓprologe //
// And here begynneth the Monkys tale .
I wole be wayle in maneer of tregedye .
Þe harm of hem þat stondeth in heeygh degre .
And fellen soo þat there nas no remedye .
To bryngen hem out of here aduersite .
For certeyn whanne that fortune lust to fle .
There may no man of hire the cours witholde .
Leet no man trustne on blynd prosꝑper/parite .
Beeth waar be these ensamples yonge and oolde .
At lucifer though he an angel weere .
And nought a man at hym I wole begynne .
For they fortune may noon angel dere .
From heey degre yit fell he for his synne .
Doun in to helle wheere as he yit is ynne .
O lucifer bryghtest of angelis alle .
Now art thou sathanas that mayst not twynne .
Out of myserie in whiche thou art falle .
¶ Loo Adam in the feeld of Damacene
With goddis owne fyngir wrought was he
And nat be getyng of mannes sperme vncleene .
And welte all paradis sauynge oo tree .
Hadde neuere worldly man soo heey degree .
As Adam ; til he for his gouernaunce .
Was dryuen out of his heey prosꝑper/parite .
To labour and to helle and to myschaunce .
¶ Loo sampson whiche was annunciate .
Be the angel longe or his natiuite .
And was to god almyghty consecrate .
And stood in nobles whiles he myghte see
Was neuere swiche anothir as was he
To speken of strengthe and therto hardynesse .
But to his wyues tolde he his secree .
¶ Thurgh whiche he slow hym selue for wrecchednesse .
Sampson this noble and myghty campioun .
Withouten weepne saue his handis tweye .
He slow and alle to rente the lyoun .
Toward his weddyng walkynge be the weye .
His false wyf coude hym soo plese and preye .
Til sche his counseil knew and sche vntrewe .
¶ Vn to hise foos his counseil gan be wreye .
And hym forsook and took anothir newe .
An hundred foxes took Sampson for yre .
And alle here tayles he to gidere bond .
And sette þe foxes tayles al on a fyre .
For he in euery tayle hadde putte a brond .
And thei brente alle the cornes in that lond .
¶ And alle here olyues and here vynes eek .
A thousand men eek he slowgh with his hond
And hadde no wepne but an asse cheeke .
Whanne thei weere slayn soo thursted hym that he .
Was wol neeygh lorn for whiche he gan to preye .
Þat god wolde of his peyne haue som pite .
And seende hym drynk or ellis muste he deye .
¶ And of this asse cheeke þat was soo drye .
Out of a wang tooth sprang anoon a welle .
Of whiche he drank I nough shortly to seye .
Þus halpe hym god as Iudicıı̄un can telle .
Be very force at Gasan on a nyght .
Maugre philistiens of that cite .
The gate of the toun he hath vp plyght .
¶ And on his bakke caried hem hath he
Heeygh on an hille wheere as men myghte see .
O noble al myghti Sampson leef and deere .
Ne hadde thou told to wommen thi secre .
In all this world ne hadde there been thi peere .
Þis Sampson neuere cyther drank ne wyn .
Ne on his heed cam rasour noon ne schere
¶ Be precepte of the massager deuyn .
For all his strengthe was in his heer .
And fully twenty yeer be yeer .
He hadde of Israel þe gouernaunce .
But aftir soone schall he weepe manye a teere .
For wommen schuln bryngen hym to mischaunce .
Vn to his lemman Dalida he tolde .
¶ That in his heeris all his strengthe lay .
And falsely to his foo men sche hym solde .
And sleepynge vppon hire barme vppon a day .
Sche made to clippe or schere his heer away .
And made his foomen all his craft aspien .
And whan that thei hym fond in swiche array .
Þei bond hym faste and putte out his eeyen .
¶ But or his heer was clipped or schaue .
There was no bond that myghte hym bynde .
But now is he in prisoun putte in a kaue .
Wheere as thei made hym at the querne grynde .
O noble Sampson strengest of mankynde .
O whilom iuge in glorie and richesse .
Now mayst thou weep with thyn eeyen blynde .
¶ Sithens thou art fro wele falle in to wrecchednesse .
The eende of these caytiffes was as I schall seye .
His foomen made a feste vpon a day .
And made hym as here fool beforn hym pley .
And this was / in a temple of greet array .
But at the laste he made a foul affray .
For he two postes schook and made hem falle .
¶ And doun fell temple and all there it lay .
And slow hym seluen and eek his foomen alle .
Þis is to say the prynces euerichoon .
¶ And eek a thousand bodies weere thei slayn .
With fallyng of þe greete temple of stoon .
Of Sampson ne wole I no more seyn .
Beeth waar of this ensample oold and pleyn .
Þat no man telle his counseil til here wyues
Of swiche thyng as thei wolde haue secre fayn .
If that it touche here lymes or here lyues .
¶ Of Ercule the souereyn conquerour .
Syngen his werkes lewede and heey renoun .
For in his tyme of strengthe he baar þe flour
He slow and refte þe skyn fro the lyoun .
He of Sentawres leyde þe bost adoun .
He Arpyes slow the cruell bryddes felle
He goldene apples rafte the dragoun .
¶ He drow out Serberois þe hound of helle .
He slow the cruel tiraunt Buserus .
And made his hors to freten hym flessh and boon
He slow the verrey serpent venymous .
Of Achilles two hornes brak he oon .
And he slow cacus in a caue of stoon
¶ He slow the geaunt Anteus the stronge .
He slow þe grisly boor and that anoon .
And baar the heed vpon his nekke longe .
Was neuere wyght sithen þe world began .
Þat slow so manye monstres as dede he .
Thurgh out this wilde world his name ran .
¶ What for his strengthe and for his bounte .
And euery rewme wente he for to see .
¶ He was soo strong that no man myghte hym lette .
And bothe the worldes eende seyth trophe .
In stede of bondes he a piler sette .
A lemman hadde this noble Campyoun .
Þat hyghte dyamyre fresshe as may .
And as the clerkes maden mencioun .
¶ Sche hath hym sent a sherte fresshe and gay .
¶ Allas this scherte and welawey .
Enuenymed was subtelly with all
Þat or that he hadde wered it half a day
It made his bonys fro his flessh falle
But natheles som clerk hire excusen
Be oon that hyghte nessus þat it maked .
¶ Be as be may I wile hire nought accusen .
But on his bak the sherte he wereth al naked .
Til that his flessh was for þe venym blaked .
And whanne he saw noon othir remedie
In hoote coles he hath hym selue raked .
For with no venym deynede he to deye .
Thus starf this worthi myghti Ercules .
¶ Loo who may truste on fortune ony throwe .
For hym that foleweth al this world of prees .
Or he be waar is ofte leyd full lowe .
Full wys is he that hym selue can knowe .
Beeth waar for whanne þat fortune lust to glose .
Þanne wayteth sche hire man doun to throwe .
Be swiche a wey as he wolde leest suppose .
The myghty trone þe precious tresour
Þe glorious septre and reall mageste
Þat hadde þe kyng Nabugodonosor
With tunge vnnethe may discryued be .
He twyes nam ierusalem þe Citee
Þe vessell of the temple he with hym ladde .
At Babiloyne was his souereyn see .
¶ In whiche his glorie and his delit he hadde .
Þe fayreste children of þe blood royall .
Of Ierusalem he dede do gelde anoon .
And made ecche of hem to been his cherl .
Among alle othire Danyel was oon .
Þat was þe wyseste child of euerichon
For he the dremes of þe kyng expounede .
Where as in Caldey clerk was there noon .
Þat wiste to what fin his dremes sownede .
This proude kyng leet make a statur of gold .
Sixti cubites long and seuene in breede .
To whiche ymage bothe yong and oold .
Comaunded he to loute and haue in dreede .
Or in a fourneys full of flames reede .
He schall be brent þat wolde not obeye .
But neuere wolde assente to that deede .
Danyel ne his yonge felawes tweye .
Þis kyng of kynges proud and elate .
He wende god that sitte in mageste .
Ne myghte hym nought be reue of his estate .
But sodeynly he loste his dignite .
And lyk a beste hym seemede for to be .
And eet hey as an oxe and lay theroute .
In reyn with wilde bestis walkede he .
Til certeyn tyme was comen aboute .
And lyk an egles fetheres was his heeris .
¶ His nayles lyk briddis clawes weere .
God releued hym a certeyn yeeris .
And yaf hym wyt and thanne with manye a teere
He thanked god and euere his lyf in fere
Was he to doon amys no more trespas
And or that tyme he leyd was on his beere
He knew weel þat god was full of myght and grace .
His sone whiche that hyghte Balthasar .
Þat heeld the reyne aftir his fadir day .
He be his fadir coude not be waar .
For proud he was of herte and of aray .
And eek an ydolatre was he ay .
His heey estate assuyred hym in pryde
But fortune caste hym doun and there he lay .
¶ And sodeynly his reyne gan deuyde .
A feste he made vn to hise lordis alle .
Vpon a tyme he made hem blythe be .
And thanne his officeris gan he calle .
Gooth bryngeth foorth þe vesseles quod he .
Whiche that my fadir in his prosꝑper/parite .
Out of the temple of ierusalem be rafte .
And to oure heeye goddis thanke we .
Of honour that oure eldres with vs lafte .
His wyf his lordes and his concubines
Ay drunken whiles here appetit laste
Out of this noble vesseles sundry wynes .
And on a wal this kyng his eeyen caste .
And saw an hand armles þat wroot full faste .
¶ For feer of whiche he qwook and syghede soore .
Þis hand that Balthasar made soo soore agast .
Wroot mane techel phares and no more .
In all that lond magicien was thernoon .
Þat coude expoune what this lettre mente .
But Danyel expouned it anoon .
And seyde kyng god to thi fadir sente .
¶ Glorie and honour regne tresour and rente .
And he was proud and no thyng god ne dradde
And therfore god greet wrathe vpon hym sente .
And hym be rafte þe reyne that he hadde .
He was out cast of mannes companye .
With assis was his habitacioun .
And eet hey as a beste in weet and drye .
¶ Til that he knew be grace and be resoun .
Þat god of heuene hath dominacioun .
Ouir euery reyne and euery creature .
And thanne hadde god of hym compassioun .
And hym restored his reygne and his figure .
Eek thou that art his sone art proud also .
And knowest alle these thynges preuyly .
¶ And art rebell to god and art his foo .
Thou drank eek of his vesselis boldly .
Þi wyf eek and thi wenches synfully .
Drank of the same vesselis sundry wynes .
And heryed fals goddis cursedly .
Therfore to the shapen greet peyne is .
This hand was sent fro god þat on þe wal
¶ Wroot mane techel phares truste me
Thi reyne is doon thou weyest not at all .
Diuided is thi reyne and it schall be .
To medes and to ꝑper/parses youen quod he .
And thilke same nyght the kyng was slawe .
And Darius occupieth his degre .
They he therto ne hadde ryght neythir ne lawe .
Lordynges heer be ensample may yee take .
How that in lordshipe is no sykernesse .
For whanne fortune wole a man forsake .
He bereth awey his reyne and his rychesse .
And eek his freendis bothe more and lesse .
And what man hath freendis thurgh fortune .
Myshappe wile maken hem ennemyes I gesse .
This prouerbe is full sooth and ful commune .
¶ Cenobia of Palymer the qweene .
As wryten ꝑper/parsyens of hire noblesse .
Soo worthi was in armes and soo keene .
Þat no wyght passede hire in hardynesse .
Ne in lynage ne in othir gentilnesse .
Of kynges blood of ꝑper/parcy is sche descended .
I sey that sche hadde nought most fayrnesse .
But of hire schap sche myghte not been amended .
¶ From childhood I fynde that sche fledde .
Office of wommen and in to wode sche wente .
And manye a wylde hertis blood sche schedde .
With arewes broode that sche to hym sente .
Sche was so swyft that sche anoon hem hente .
And whanne that sche was eldere sche wolde kille .
Leouns liberdes and beres alto rente .
And in hire armes welde hem at hire wille .
¶ Sche durste wilde bestis dennes seeke .
And renne in þe mounteyne al þe nyght .
And sleepen vndir a busshe sche coude eek .
Wrastelen be verray force and myght .
With ony yong man weere he neuere soo wyght .
Þere myghte no thyng in hire armes stonde .
Sche kepte hire maydenhood from euery wyght .
To no man deyned hire to be bonde .
¶ But at the laste hire freendis han hire maried .
To Odonak a prynce of that cite .
Al weere it soo that sche hem longe taried .
And yee schall vndirstonde how that he .
Hath swiche fantasies as hadde sche .
But natheles whanne thei weere knyt in feere .
Þei lyueden in ioye and in felicite .
For ecche of hem hadde othir leef and deere .
Sauf oo thyng þat sche nolde neuere assente .
¶ Be no wey þat he shulde be hire lye .
But ones for it was hire pleyne entente .
To haue a child þe world to multeplie .
And also soone as sche myghte aspie .
Þat sche was nought with childe with that deede .
Thanne wole sche suffren hym doon his fantasie .
Eft soone and not but ones out of dreede .
¶ And if sche weere with childe at thilke caste .
Nomore schulde he pleye thilke game .
Til fourti dayes weere paste .
Þanne wolde sche ones suffren hym doo þe same .
All weere this Odenake wilde or tame .
He gat nomore of hire for thus sche seyde .
It was to wyues leccherye and schame .
In othir caas if that men with hem pleyde .
¶ Two sones be this Odenak hadde sche .
Þe whiche sche kepte in vertu and in lettrure .
But now vn to oure tale turne we .
I say that worshipfull creature .
And wys therwith and large with mesure .
Soo penyble in the werre and curteys eek
No more labour myghte in werre endure .
Was noon though all this world me shulde seeke .
¶ Hire riche aray myght not be told .
As weel in vessel as in clothyng .
Sche was al clad in perre and in gold .
And eek sche lefte nought for noon huntyng .
To haue of sundry tunges folk knowynge .
Whanne that sche leyser hadde and for to entende .
To leerne bookes was all hire lyking .
How sche in vertu myghte hire lyf dispende .
¶ And shortely of this storie for to entrete
Soo doughty was hire hosebonde as sche .
Þat thei conquered manye regnes grete .
In þe orient with manye a fayr cite .
Apꝑper/partenaut vn to þe mageste .
Of Rome and with strong hond heeld hem faste .
Ne neuere myghte here foomen doon hem flee .
Ay whiles þat Odenak dayes laste
¶ Here batayles who soo list hem for to reede .
¶ Ageyn soper Þe kyng and othire moo .
And how that alle the processes felle in deede .
Why sche conquerede and what title hadde therto .
And aftir of hire myscheef and of hire woo
How that sche was beseeged and I take
Leet hym vn to my maystir Petrark goo .
Þat wryt Inowh of this I vndirtake .
¶ Whanne Odenak was deed sche myghtily .
Þe regnes heeld and with hire ꝓpropre hond
Ageyn hire foos sche faught trewely .
Þat there nas kyng ne prynce in all that lond .
Þat he nas glad if he that grace fond .
Þat sche ne wolde vpon his lond werreye .
With hire thei made alliaunce be bond .
To been in pees and leete hire ryde and pleye .
¶ Þe emꝑper/parour of Rome Claudius .
Ne hym beforn þe Romayn galiene .
Ne durste neuere be soo coragious .
Ne noon Ermyn ne noon Egipciene .
Ne surriene ne noon arabiene .
With Inne þe feld þat durste with hire fyght .
Lest that sche wolde with hire hondis hym sleen .
Or with hire meyne putten hem to flyght .
¶ In kyngis habite wente hire sones two .
As heyres of here reignes alle .
And hermanno and Tymalito .
Here names weere as ꝑper/parsyens hem calle .
But ay fortune hath ay in hire hony galle .
This myghty qweene may no while endure .
Fortune out of hire reyne made hire falle .
To wrecchednesse and to mysaduenture .
¶ Aurelion whan that þe gouernaunce .
Of Rome come in to his handis tweye .
He shoop vp on this qweene to doo vengeaunce .
And with his legiouns he took his weye .
Toward Cenoby and shortly for to seye .
He made hire flee and atte laste hire hente .
And fetered hire and eek hire children tweye .
And wan þe lond and hoom to Rome thei wente .
Among these othire thynges that he wan .
Hire char that wrought with gold was and perre .
Þis greete Romayn this Aurelian .
Hath with hym lad for that men shulde see .
Beforn his triumphe walketh sche .
With gilt cheynes on hire nekke hangynge .
¶ Corouned sche was as aftir hire degre .
And full of perry charged hire clothyng .
Allas fortune sche that whilom was .
Dreedfull to kynges and to Emꝑper/parouris .
Now gaureth al the peeple on hire allas .
And sche that helmed was in starke stoures
Schall on hire heed now bere a vytremyte .
¶ And sche that baar þe septre full of floures
Schall bere a distaf hire cost for to qwyte .
O noble o woorthi petre glorie of spayne .
Whom fortune heeld soo hyghe in mageste .
Weel oughte men thi pitous deth compleyne .
Thi bastard brothir made the to fle .
And aftir at a seege be subtilte .
¶ Thou weere be trayed and lad to his tente .
Wheere as he with his owne hond slow the .
Succedynge in thi reyne and in thi rente
The feeld of snow with þe egle blak therynne .
Caught with þe lyme reed coloures as the gleede .
He brewe this cursednesse and al the synne .
Þe wykkede nest was werkere of these needis .
¶ Nought Charles Olyuere þat ay took good heed .
Of trouthe and honour but Armorekke .
Geniloun Olyuer corrupt for meede .
Broughtest this worthi kyng in swich brekke .
Worthi Petre kyng of Cipre also .
Þat Alisaundre wan be heey maistrie
Full manye an heethene wroughtest thou full woo .
¶ Of whiche thyn owne lieges hadden enuye .
And for no thyng but for thi chiualrie .
Thei in thi bed han slayn the be þe morewen .
Thus gan fortune gouerne and gye .
And out of ioye bryngen in to sorewe .
Of Melane greet Barnabo viscounte .
God of delit and scourge of Lumbardie .
Why shulde not I thi fortune acounte .
Sithen in estate thou clumben weere soo hyghe
Thi brotheris sone þat was thi double allie .
For he thi neuewe was and sone in lawe .
With ynne his prisoun made the to deye .
But whi ne how wote I þat thou weere slawe .
Of the eerl Hugelyne of Pyse þe langoure .
There may no tunge telle for pite .
¶ But litil out of pyse stant a tour .
In whiche tour in prisoun putte was he .
And with hym been his litel children thre .
Allas fortune it was greet cruelte .
Swiche briddes for to putte in swich a cage .
Dampned he was to deye in that prisoun .
¶ For Roger whiche that bisshop was of Pyse .
Hadde on hym maad a fals suggestioun .
Thurgh whiche þe peeple gan on hym aryse .
And putten hym to prisoun in swiche a wyse .
As yee haue herd and mete and drynk he hadde .
Soo small þat vnnethe it may suffise .
And therwith all it was full poore and badde .
¶ On a day befel that in that hour
Whanne that his was wont to be wrought .
Þe gaillour shette the dores of þe tour .
He herde it weel but he saugh it nought .
And in his herte anoon there fel a thought
Til thei for hungir wolde doon hym deyen .
Allas quod he allas that I was wrought .
Therwith the teeris fel fro his eeyen .
¶ His yonge sone thre yeer was of aage .
Vn to hym seyde fadir why doo yee weepe .
Whanne wole þe gailoᵘur bryngen oure potage .
Is there no morsell breed þat do keepe .
I am soo hungry that I may not sleepe .
Now wolde god that I myghte sleepen euere .
Þanne shulde noon hungir in myn wombe creepe .
There is no thyng sauf breed þat me weere leeuere .
¶ Þus day be day this child gan to crye .
Til in his faderis barm adoun it lay .
And seyde fareweel fadir I mote deye .
And kyssede his fadir and deyde the same day .
And whanne þe wofull fadir deed hym say .
For woo his armes two he gan to byte .
And seyde allas fortune and welawey .
Thyn fals wheel my woo I may al wite .
¶ His childre þat it for hungir was .
Þat he his armes gnow and nought for woo .
And seyden fadir doo nought soo allas .
But rathere ete þe flessh vpon vs two .
Oure flessh ye yaff vs take oure flesshe vs fro .
And ete ynowgh ryght thus to hym thei seyde .
And aftir that with ynne a day or two.
Thei leyde hem doun in his lappe and deyde .
¶ Hymself dispeyred eek for hungir starf .
Thus eended is þe myghti eerl of Pyse .
From hygh estate fortune fro hym karf .
Of his tregetrye it oughte Inowh suffise
Who soo wole heeren it in a lengere wyse
Reedeth þe greete Poete of ytalie .
Þat hyghte Daunte for he can it deuyse
Fro poynt to poynt nought oo woord wole he fayle
¶ Al though þat Nero weere as vicious .
As ony feend that lyth full lowe adoun .
Yit he as telleth vs Swetheneus .
Þis wyde world hadde in subieccioun .
Bothe est and west and Septemtrioun .
Of rubies zaphires and of ꝑper/parles white .
Weere all his brouded vp and doun .
For he in gemmes greete gan delite .
¶ More delicat more pompous of aray .
More proud was neuere Emꝑper/parour thanne he
Þat ilke cloth that he hadde wered a day .
Aftir that tyme he nolde it neuere see .
Nettes of gold threed hadde he greet plente .
To fisshen in Tibre whan hym list to pleye .
His lustes as lawe in his degre .
For fortune as his freend wolde hym obeye .
¶ He Rome brente for his delicacye .
Þe senatours he slough vpon a day .
To heeren how that men wolde weepe and crye .
And slough his brothir and by his sustir .
His moodir made he in pitous aray .
For he hire wombe slitte to beholde .
Wheere he conceyued was soo weylawey .
Þat he soo litil of his moodir tolde .
¶ No teer out of his eeyen for that syghte .
Ne cam but seyde a fayr womman was sche .
Greet wondir is that he coude or myghte .
Be domesman of hire deed bewte .
Þe wyn to brynge comaunded he .
He drank anoon noon othir woo he made .
Whanne myght is ioyned vn to cruelte .
Allas to deepe wolde þe venym wade .
¶ In yougthe a maystir hadde this Emꝑper/parour .
To teechen hym lettrure and curtesie .
For of moralite he was the flour .
As in his tyme but if bookes lye .
And whiles his maistir hadde of hym maistrye .
He made hym soo cunnynge and soo souple .
Þat long tyme it was or tyrannye
Or ony vice in hym durste vncouple .
¶ This seneca of whiche I deuyse .
Be cause Nero hadde of hym swich dreede
For he for vices wolde hym chastice
Discretly as be woord and nought be dreede
Sire wolde he seyn an Emꝑper/parour mote neede
Be vertuous and hate tirannye .
For whiche he hym in bath made to bleede
On bothe his armes til he must deye
¶ This Nero hadde eek of a custumance .
In yougthe ayen his maistir for to rise .
Whiche aftirward hym thoughte a greet greuaunce
Therfore he made hym deye in this wyse .
But natheles this Senek the wyse .
Chees in a bath to deye in this maneere .
Rathere thanne han anothir turmentrie .
And thus hath Nero slayn his maistir deere .
¶ Now fell it soo þat fortune lust no lengere .
Þe heeygh pryde of Nero to cherice .
For though he weere strong yit was sche strengere .
Sche thoughte thus be god I am to nyce .
To sette a man þat is fulfild of vice .
In heeygh degre an Emꝑper/parour hym calle .
Be god out of his seete I wole hym trice .
Whanne he leest weeneth sonnest shall he falle .
¶ The peeple roos vpon hym on a nyght
For his defaute and whanne he it aspied .
Out of his dores anoon he hath hym dyght .
Allone and there he wende han been allied .
He knokkede faste and ay þe more he cried
Þe fastere shetten thei þe dores alle .
Tho wiste he weel he hadde hym selue mysgyed .
And wente his wey no lengere durste he calle .
¶ Þe peeple cryede and romblede vp and doun .
Þat with his eeris herde he how thei seyde
Wheere is this fals tretour this Neroun .
For feer almost out of his witte abrayde
And to his goddis pitously he seyde .
For socour but it myght not be tyde .
For dreede of this hym thoughte that he deyde .
And ran in to a gardyn hym to hide .
¶ And in this gardyn fond he cherles twey .
That seeten be a feer full greet and reed .
And to þe cherlis tweye he gan to preye .
To sleen hym and to gerden of his heede
Þat to his body whanne that he weere deed .
Weere no despit doon for his diffame .
Hym selue he slough he coude no bettere reed .
Of whiche fortune lough and made a game .
¶ Was neuere capitayn vndir a kyng .
Þat reignes mo putte in subieccioun
Ne strengere was in feeld of alle thyng
As in his tyme ne grettere of renoun .
Ne more pompous in heey presumpcioun .
Þanne Oliferne whiche fortune ay keste .
Soo likerously and ladde hym vp and doun .
¶ Til that his heed was of or that he wiste .
Nought oonly that this world hadde of hym awe .
For lesyng of richesse and of liberte .
But he made eueri man reneye his lawe .
Nabugodonosor was lord seyde he .
Noon othir go schulde honoured be .
Ayens his hest no wyght daar trespace .
Sauf in Betulia a strong cite .
Wheere Eliachim a prest was of that place .
But take keep of the deth of Olyferne .
¶ Amydde his oost he dronken lay a nyght
Withynne his tente large as is a beerne .
And yit for all his pompe and al his myght .
Iudith a womman as he lay vpryght .
Sleepynge his heued of smoot and fro his tente .
Full preuely sche staal from euery wyght .
What needeth it of kyng Antiochus .
To tellen his heey and real mageste .
His heey pride his werke venemous .
For swiche anothir was neuere noon as he .
Reedeth whiche þat he was in Machabe .
And reedeth þe proude woordis þat he seyde .
And whi he fel from his prosꝑper/parite .
And in an hill how wrecchedly he deyde .
¶ Fortune hym hadde enhaunced soo in pryde .
Þat verily he wende he myghte atteyne .
Vn to þe sterres vppon eueri syde .
And in a balaunce to weye þe mounteyne .
And alle þe floodis of þe see restreyne .
And goddis peeple hadde he most in hate .
Hem wolde he sle in torment and peyne .
Weenyng that god ne myghte his pride abate .
¶ And for that Nichamour and Tymothe .
With iewes weere venqwisshed myghtily .
Vn to þe iewes swich an hate hadde he .
Þat he hadde greythed his chaar full hastely .
And swoor and seyde full despitously .
Vn to Ierusalem he wolde efte soone
To wreken his Ire on it full cruelly .
But of his purpos he was lette full soone .
¶ God of his manace hym soo soore smoot
With inuisible wounde ay vncurable .
Þat in his guttes karf soo and boot
That his peynes weere importable .
And certeynly þe wreche was resonable .
For manye mannes guttes dede he payne .
But fro his purpos cursed and dampnable .
For all his smert he nolde hym restreyne .
¶ But bad anoon apparaylen his oost .
And sodeynly or he was of it waar .
God daunted al his pryde and all his bost .
For he soo sore fel out of his chare .
Þat hurte his lymes and his skyn to tare .
Soo that he ne myghte goo ne ryde .
But in a chayer men aboute hym baar .
Al for brused bothe bak and syde
¶ Þe wreche of god hym smoot so cruelly .
That in his body wykkede wermes crepte .
And therwith all he stank so horribely .
Þat noon of all his meyne þat hym kepte .
Whethir soo that he wook or ellis slepte .
Ne myght nought the stynk of hym endure .
In this mescheef he waylede and eek wepte .
And knew god lord of euery creature .
¶ To all his oost and to hym selue also .
Full lothsum was the stynk of his careyne .
No man myghte hym bere to ne fro .
And in his stynke and in his orrible peyne .
He starf full wrecchedly in a mounteyne .
Thus hath this robbour and homicide .
Þat manye a man made to weepe and pleyne .
Swich guerdoun as belongeth vn to pride .
¶ Þe storie of Alisaundre is soo comune .
Þat euery wyght that hath discrecioun .
Hath herd somwhat or all of his fortune .
Þis wyde world as in conclusioun .
He wan be strengthe or for his heey renoun .
Thei weeren glad for pees vn to hym seende .
Þe pride of man and beste he leyde a doun .
Wheere soo he came vn to þe worldis eende .
¶ Comparisoun myghte neuere be maked .
Betwixen hym and anothir conquerour
For al this world for dreede of hym hath qwaked .
He was of knyghthood and of fredom flour .
Fortune hym made þe eyr of hire honour .
Saaf wyn and wommen no thyng myghte aswage .
His heey entent in armes and labour .
Soo was he full of louynge corage .
¶ What pitee weere it to hym though I yow tolde .
Of Darius and an hundred thousand moo.
Of kynges prynces eerlis bolde .
Whiche he conquered and broughte hem in to woo .
I say as fer as man may ride or goo .
Þe world was his what schulde I more deuyse .
For though I write and tolde yow euere moo .
Of his knyghthood it myghte not suffice .
¶ Twelue yeer he reygned as seyth Machabe .
Philippes sone of Macedonie he was .
Þat first was kyng of Grece the contree .
O worthi gentil Alisaundre allas .
Þat euere schulde falle swiche a caas .
Enpoysouned of thi folk thou weere .
Thyn . s . fortune hath turned in to an aas .
And yit for the ne weep sche neuere a teere
¶ Who schall yeue teres men to compleyne .
Þe deth of gentilnesse and of franchise .
That al þe world weelded in his demeyne .
And yit hym thoughte it myghte not suffise .
Soo full was his corage of heey empryse .
Allas who schall me helpe to endite .
Fals fortune and poysoun to despise .
Þe whiche two of al this woo I wyte .
¶ Be wysedom manheed and be labour .
From humbleheed and fro royal mageste .
Vproos he Iulius þe conquerour .
Þat all the occident be lond and see .
Be strengthe of hand or elles be trete .
And vn to Rome made hem tributarie .
And sithens of Rome þe Emꝑper/parour was he
Til that fortune wax his aduersarie .
O myghti Cesar that in tessalie .
Ayens Pompeus fadir thyn in lawe .
That of the orient hadde al þe chiualrie .
As fer as that þe day begynneth dawe .
Theigh thurgh thyn knyghthood hast hem take and slawe .
Saue fewe folk þat with Pompeus fledde .
Thurgh whiche thou puttest all þe orient in awe .
Thanke fortune þat soo weel the spedde
¶ But now a litil while I wole be waile
Þis Pompeus this noble gouernour .
Of Rome whiche that fleygh at this bataille .
I sey oon of his men a fals traitour
His heed of smoot to wynnen hym fauoᵘur .
Of Iulius and hym þe heed broughte .
Allas Pompey of þe orient conquerour .
Þat fortune vn to swich a funte broughte .
¶ To Rome ayeen repeyreth Iulius .
With his triumphe laureate full heeye .
But on a tyme Brutus Cassius .
Þat euere hadde of his estate envie .
Full priuely hadde maad conspiracie .
Ayens this Iulius in subtil wyse .
And cast the place in whiche he schulde deye .
With boydekyns as I schall yow deuyse .
¶ Þis Iulius to þe Capithole wente .
Vpon a day as he was wont to goon .
And in þe Capitole anoon hym hente .
Þis false Brutus and his foule foon .
And steked hym with boydekyns anoon .
With manye a wounde and thus thei leet hym lye .
But neuere gronte he at no strook but oon .
Or elles at two but if his storie lye .
¶ Soo manly was this Iulius of herte .
And soo weel loued estatly honesti
Þat though his deedly woundes soo soore smerte .
His mantel ouir his hepes caste he .
For no man schulde see his pryuitee .
And as he lay on deynge in a traunce .
And wiste verily that deed was he .
Of honeste yit hadde he remembraunce .
¶ Lucane to this storie I recomende .
And to sweton and to valerius also .
Þat of this storie wryteth woord and eende .
How that these greete conquerours two .
Fortune was first freend and sithen a foo .
No man ne truste vpon his fauour longe .
But haue hire in a wait eueremo .
Witnesse on alle these conquerours stronge .
¶ This riche Cresus whilom kyng of lyde .
Of whiche Cresus Cyquus soore hym dradde
Yit was he caught amonges al his pryde
And to be brent men to the feer hym ladde .
But swiche a reyn doun fro the walkene shadde .
Þat slough the feer and made hym to eschape .
But to be waar yit no grace he hadde .
Til fortune on þe galewes made hym gape .
¶ Whanne he escaped was he can not stente .
For to begynne a newe reyn ayeen .
He wende weel for that fortune hym sente .
Swich happe that he escaped thurgh þe reyne .
Þat of his foos he myghte not be slayn .
Swiche a sweuene vpon a nyght he mette .
Of whiche he was soo proud and eek fayne .
Þat in vengeaunce he al his herte sette .
¶ Vpon a tree he was as hym thoughte .
Þere Iubiter hym weesh bothe hals and syde .
And phebus eek a fayr towaile hym broughte .
To dryen hym with and therfore wax his pride
And to his doughtir þat stood hym besyde .
Whiche that he knew in heey sentence habounde .
He badde hire tellen hym what it signefiede .
And sche his dremes began ryght thus expounde .
¶ Þe tre quod sche þe galewes is to meene .
And Iubiter betokeneth snow and reyn .
And Phebus with his towaile soo cleene .
Thoo been the sonne stremes for to seyn .
Thou schalt an hanged be fadir certeyn .
Reyn schall the wasshe and sonne schall þe dreye .
Thus warned sche hym full plat and full playn .
His doughtir that called was phanie .
¶ An honged was Cresus þe proude kyng .
His royal trone myghte hym not auaile .

To don thys synne ben eyther slayen or schente
¶ How may this wayke wōmmām haue thys strengeth
Hir to defende a gayn thys renegat
O golyas vnmesurable of lengeth
How myght dauid make the so maat
So ȝonge ⁊and of armure desolate
How dirste he loke vppon thy dredful face
Whel may mēm sen hit was but godes grace
¶ Who ȝaf Iudith corage or hardynesse
To slen hym olefernus in hys tente
And to delyueren out of wrecchednesse
The peple of god y sey for thys entente
That ryght as god spiryt and vigor sent
To hem and saued hem out of meschaunce
So sent he myght ⁊and vigor to custaunce
¶ Forth gooth hir schyp thorugh on the narow mouth
Of Iubaltar and septe dryuynge ay
Som tyme west ⁊and som tyme north ⁊and southe
And som tyme este ful many a wery day
Tyl crystes modir blessyd be scho ay
Hath schapēm thorugh hir endeles goodnesse
To make an ende of al hir heuynesse
¶ Now late vs stynt of custaıı̄unce but a throwe
And speke we of the romayn emꝑper/parour
That out of surrye hath by lettres knowe
The slaughter of crystene folke ⁊and dishonour
Don to hys doughter by a false traytour ¶
I mene the cursed wycked sowdonasse
That at the fest let slen bothe more and lesse
¶ For whych thys emꝑper/paroure hath sent a non
Hys senatour with ryal ordinaunce
And other lordes god wot many on
On surreyns to taken hye veniaunce
They brennen slen and bryngen hēm to meschaunce
Ful many a day this ys the ende
Homward to rome they schapen hēm to wende
¶ Thys senatour repayreth with victorye
To romeward seylynge ful reyally
And met the schip dryuynge as seyth the storye
In whych custaunce sit ful petously
Ne no thynge knew he what scho was ne why
Scho was in such array ne scho nel seye
Of hir estaat thow scho scholde deye
¶ He bryngeth hir to rome and to hys wyf
He ȝaf hir and hir ȝonge sone also
And with the senatour scho ledde hir lyf
Thys kan oure lady brynge out of woo
Wooful custance and many an other moo
And longe tyme dwelled scho in that place
In holy werkes euer as was hir grace
¶ The senatours wyf hir aunt was
But for al that scho knew hir neuer the more
I wyl no lenger taryen in thys caas
But to kynge alla whych y spake of ȝore
That for hys wyf wepeth and syketh sore
I wol retorne ⁊and lete y wol custaıı̄unce
Vndir the senatoures gouernaıı̄unce
¶ Kynge alla whych that had hys modir slayn
Vppon a day fyl in suche repentaıı̄unce
That yf schortly tellēm schal and playn
To rome he cometh to resceyue hys penaunce
And put hym the popes ordinaunce
In hyȝ ⁊and lowe and ihu cryste besought
For ȝeue hys wycked werkes that he wrought
¶ The fame a non thorugh rome town ys born
How alla kynge schal come in pilgrimage
By herberiours that wentēm hym by forn ¶
For whych the senatour as was vsage
Rood hym a ȝen and many of hys lynage
As wel to schewe hys hyȝ magnificence
As to don eny kynge a reuerence
¶ Greet cheer doth thys noble senatour
To kynge alla and he to hym also
Euerych of hem doth other gret honoure
And so byfil that in a day ortwo
Thys senatour ys to kynge alla go
To feste and schortly yf y schal not lye
Custances sone in hys companye
¶ Som mēm wold seyn atte request of custance
Thys senatour hath lad thys chylde to feste
I may not tellen euery circumstance
Be as be may ther was he atte leste
But soth is this that at hys moderes heste
By forn alla durynge the mete space
The childe stod lokynge in the kynges face
¶ Thys alla kynge hath of thys child gret wondir
And to the senatour he he seyde a non
Whos ys that fayre childe that stondeth ȝondir
I not ꝙquod he by god and by seynt iohn
A modir he hath but fadir hath he non
That y of woot and schortly in a stounde
He to alla how thys childe was founde
¶ But god woot ꝙquod thys senatour also
So vertous a lyuyer in my lyf
Ne saw y neuer as scho ne herd of mo
Of wordly wymmēm mayde ne wyf
I dar wel sayn scho had leuer a knyf
Thorough out hir breste þan ben a wommām wykke
Ther ys no man cowde brynge hir to that prykke
¶ Now was thys childe as lyke vnto custance
As possible as ys a creature to be
Thys alla hath the face in remēmbraunce
Of dame custaunce ⁊and ther on mused he
If that the childes modir were aught scho
That ys hys wyf and preuely syghte
And spedde hym fro the table that he mıyghte
¶ Parfay he thought the fantome ys yn myn hed ¶
I owght demen of skylful iuggemēmt
That in the salt see my wyf ys ded
And afterward he mad hys argumēmt
What woot y yf that cryst hath hedir sent
My wyf by see as wel as he hur sent
To my contre fro thennes that scho was went
¶ And after noon hom wᵗith the senatour
Gooth alla forto sen thys wondir chaunce
Thys senatour doth alla gret honoure
And hastyfly he sent after custance
But trysteth wel hir lyste nought to daunce
Whan that scho wyste wherfor was that sonde
Vnnethe vppon hir fet scho myght stonde
¶ Whan alla saugh hys wyf fayre he hir grette
And wepte that hit was reuthe forto se
For at the firste loke he on hir sette
He knew wel verryly that hit was scho
And for sorow as dombe stant as a tre
So was hir hert schet in hir distresse
Whan scho remēmbred hys vnkyndenesse
¶ Twyes scho swowneth in hys owne syght
He weep and hym excuseth pytously
Now god qd he and hys halwes bryght
So wysly an my soule as haue mercy
That of ȝoure harme as gulteles am I
As ys maurice my sone so lyk ȝoure face
Elles the fende me fecche out of thys place
¶ Longe was the sobbynge and the vtter peyne
Or that hir wooful hertes myght sese
Gret was the pyte forto her hem pleyne
Thorugh whych pleyntes gan hir woo encrese
I pray ȝow alle my labour to relese
I may not tellen her woo vntyl to morowe
I am so wery forto speke of here sorowe
¶ But fynally whan that the soth ys wyste
That alla gyltles was of her woo
I trowe an C tymes ben they kyste
And such a blysse ys ther bytwene hem two
That saue the ioye that lasteth euer mo
Ther ys non lyke that eny creature ¶
Hath seyn or schal whyle þe world may dure
¶ Tho preyde he hir housbonde mekely
In relyef of hir longe pytous peyne
That he wolde pray hir fadir specially
That of hys maieste he wolde enclyne
Fouche saf som day wyth hym to dyne
Scho prayd hym eke he schold by no waye
Vnto hir fadir no word of hir saye
¶ Som mēm wolde sey how that the childe maurice
Doth thys message vn tyl thys emꝑper/paroure
But as y gesse alla was nought so nyce
To hym that was of so souereyn honoure
As he that ys of crystene folke the floure
Sent eny childe but hit ys bet to deme
He went hym self ⁊and so hit may wel seme
¶ Thys emꝑper/parour hath graunted gentylly
To come to dyner as he hym by sought
And wel rede I he loked bysyly
Vppon thys chylde and on hys dought̉er/re thought
Alla gooth to hys yn and as hym ought
Arrayed for thys feste in euery wyse
As ferforth as hys konnyge may suffice
¶ The morow come and alla gan hym dresse
And eke hys wyf thys emꝑper/parour forto mete
And forth they ryde in ioye ⁊and in gladnesse
And whan scho say hir fadir in the strete
Scho lyght doun and falleth hym to fete
Fadir qd scho ȝoure ȝonge chylde custaunce
Is now ful clene out of ȝoure remembraıı̄unce
¶ I am ȝoure dought̉er/re custance qd scho
That whylom ȝe sent vnto surrye
It am y fadir that in the salt see
Was put allone ⁊and dampned forto dye
Now good fadir mercy I ȝow crye
Sende me no more vnto hethenesse
But thonke my lord here of hys kyndenesse
¶ Who can the pytous ioye tellen al
By twyxte hem thre syn they ben thus y mette
But of my tale make an ende y schal
The day goth faste y wol no lenger lette ¶
Thys glad folke to dyner they hem sette
At ioye ⁊and blysse at mete y lete hēm dwelle
A thousand folde wel more than y can telle
¶ Thys childe maurice was sythen emꝑper/paroure
Mad by the pope ⁊and lyued crystenly
To crystes churche he dud gret honoure
But I let al thys story passen by
Of custance ys my tale specially
In olde romayn gestys may mēm fynde
Maurices lyf y bere hit nought in mynde
¶ Thys kynge alla whanne he hys tyme say
With hys custance hys holy wyf so swete
To engelonde be they come theryȝt way
Wher as they lyue in ioye ⁊and in quyete
But lytel whyle hit lasteth y ȝow hete
Ioy of thys worlde for tyme wyl nought a byde
Fro day to nyght hit chaungeth as the tyde
¶ Who lyued euer in such delyt a day
That ne meued eyther conscience
Or yre or talent or som kyn affray
Enuye or pruyde or passion or offense
I ne say but for thys ende thys sentence
That lytel whyle in ioye or in plesance
Lasteth the blysse of alla wᵗith custance
¶ For deth that taketh of hyȝ ⁊and low hys rent
Whan passed was a ȝer euen as y gesse
Out of thys world thys kynge alla he went
For whom custaunce hath ful greet heuynesse
Now lat vs prayen god hys soule blesse
And dame custance fynally to sey
Toward the toune of rome gooth hur wey
¶ To rome ys come thys holy creature
And fyndeth hir frendes hool ⁊and sounde
Now ys scho scaped al hur aventure
And whan scho hir fadir hath founde
Doun on knees falleth scho to grounde
Wepynge for tendirnesse in hert blythe
Scho heryeth god an C thosand sythe
¶ In vertu and in holy almesdede
They lyuedēm alle ⁊and neủer/re a sondir wēmde ¶
Tyl deth depart hem thys lyf they lede
And fareth now wel my tale ys atte an ende
Now ihu cryste that of hys myght may sende
Ioy after woo gouerne vs in hys grace
And kepe vs alle that ben in thys place

And bygynneth the tale ¶
Lordynges qd he in chirche whan y preche
I peyne me to haue an hauntēm speche
I rynge hit oute as rounde as doth a belle
For y can all by rote that y telle
My terme ys alwey on and euer was
Radix omnium malorıı̄un est cupiditas
Firste y pronounce whens that y come
And than my bulles y schewe all and som
Oure leege lordes seell of my patente
That schewe y firste my body to warente
That noman be so bolde prest ne clerke
Me to destroble of godes holy werke
And after that telle y forthe my tales
Bulles of popes and of cardinales
And priarkes and bysschoppes y schewe
And in latyn speke wordes fewe
To sauer with my predicacōmu
And forto sture men to deuocioıı̄un
Thanne schewe y forthe my longe crystall stones
I crāmmed full of cloutes and of bones
Relyques they ben as they wene echone
Thanne haue y in latoıı̄un a schildre bone
Whyche was an holy iewes schep
Goodmēm sey I take at my wordes kepe
If that thys boon be waschen in a well
If a cowȝ or calf or ox or schep swelle
That eny worme hath eten or stonge
A boute the herte or elles the longe
And hyt ys hool a non and furthermore
Of pokke and of scabbe and of euery sore
Schall euery scheep be hool that of that well
Drynke a drauȝt take hede what y telle
If that the goodman that the bestes oweth
Woll eủer/rey wyke or that the cocke croweth
Fastynge drynke of thys well a drauht
As thilke holy iew oure eldres tauȝt
Hys bestes and hys corne schall multiplye
And syres also hit heleth ielesye
And thouȝ a man be fallen in a ielous rage
Let maken with thys wat̉er/re hys patage ¶
And neuer schall he hys wyf mystryste
Thouȝ he the soth of hir defaute wyste
Alle hadde sche taken prestes two or thre
Here ys a meteyne eke that ȝe may se
He that hys honde woll putte in thys meteyne
He schall haue multyplyinge of hys greyne
Whenne he hath sowen be hit whete or otes
So that he brynge me good pens or grotes
And men and wymen o thynge y warne ȝow
If eny whyte ben in thys chirche now
That hath don synne orrible that he
Dar not for schame of hit schryuēm be
Or eny womman be sche ȝonge or olde
That hath maad hir housbonde cockwolde
Suche folke schall haue no power ne no gᵃce
To offre to my relykes in thys place
And who so fyndeth hym oute of suche blame
They will come vp and offre in goodes name
And y Assoyle hym by the auctorite
Suche as my bylle was graunted me
By thys gaude haue y wonne mery ȝer
An hondred marke sen y was ꝑper/pardoner
I stonde lyke a clerke in my pulputte
And sen lewde peple sen y sytte
I preche so as y haue lered by fore
And telle an hondred iapes more
Thenne peyne y me to strecche forthe the necke
And este and weste vppon þe peple y bekke
As doth a dowue sittynge vppon a berne
My hondes and my tonge gooth full ȝerne
That hit ys ioye to se my besynes
Of auaryce and suche cursednesse
Is all my prechynge forto maken hem fre
To ȝeue here pens and namly to me
For myn entente nouȝt ys but forto wynne
And nothynge for correccioun of synne
I recke neuer whan they ben buryed
Thouȝ that her soules gon a blackberyed
For certes many a predicacōmn
Cometh ofte tyme of euell entencōmn ¶
Som for plesaunce of folke and for flaterye
To ben avaunced by ypocrysye
And som for veyn glorye and for hate
For whenne y dar other weyes debate
Thēmne will y stynge hem with my tonge smerte
In prechynge so that he schall not sterte
To ben defamed falsly so that he
Hath trespassed or to my bretheren or to me
For thouȝ y telle not hys propre name
Men schull well knowe hit ys the same
By other signes and other circumstaunces
Thus smyte y folke that doth vs plesaunce
Thus put I oute my venym vndir hewe
Of holynesse to semen holy and trewe
But schortely myn entente y wolle devyse
I preche of no thynge but of couetyse
Therefor my tyme ys ȝit and euer was
Radyx omnium malorum est cupiditas
Thus gan y preche a ȝenste the same vice
Whyche that y vse and that ys aueryce
But thouȝ my self be gulty in that synne
Ȝit kan y make other folke to wynne
Fro aueryce and sore hem repente
But that ys not my principall entente
I preche not but for couetyse
Of thys mater hit ouȝte y now suffise
Thēmne telle hem ensamples manyon
Of olde storyes longe tyme a gon
For lewde peple louen tales olde
Whyche thynges conne they reporte and holde
What trow ȝe whyles that y may preche
And wynne golde and seluer forto teche
That y will lyue in pouert wilfully
Nay nay y thouȝt hyt neuer trewly
For y wylle and begge in sondry londes
I wille do no labour with myn hondes
Ne make baskettes and lyue ther by
By cause I wyll no leuen ydelly
I will non of the aplēms counterfete
I woll haue money malt chese and whete ¶
All were hit ȝeuen of the porest page
Other of the porest wedow in a village
All scholde her children sterue for famyn
And I will drynke the lycorest of the wyne
And haue a ioly wenche in euery toune
But herkeneth lordes in conclusioıı̄un
Ȝoure lykynge ys that y may telle a tale
Now y haue dronken a drauȝt of corny ale
By god y hope telle ȝow a thynge
That schall by resoun be at ȝoure lykynge
For thouȝ my self be a full vicious manne
A morell tale ȝit ȝow telle y talle can
Whyche iames went forto wynne
Nowȝ holde ȝoure pes my tale y wol be gynne
IN Flaundres whylom was a companye
Of ȝonge folke that haunted folye
At hasarde ryot stwes and tauernes
Harpe rybibes lutes and get̉er/renes
They dauncēm and pleyen at the dys nyȝt and day

By suꝑper/parfluyte abhominable
Here othes ben so greet and dampnable

Oure blessed lordes body they to tere
Hem thouȝt iewes rente hym nouȝt y nowȝ
And ilke of hem of others synne lowȝ
And ryȝt a non come yn then tomblesters
Fetys and small and ȝonge fruterours

Suche ben verry the deueles officers
To kendelen the and blowe the fuyre of lecherye
That ys annexed to glotenye
Ther holy wrytte take y to witnesse
That lecherye ys in wyn and dronkenesse
Lo how that dronken loth vnkyndely
Lay by hys douȝtren to vn wytyngely
So dronken he was he neste what he wrouȝte
Herodes who so hath the storyes souȝte ¶
When he of wyn was replet at hys feste
Ryȝt at hys owne table ȝaf hys heste
To slen iohn the baptiste gulteles
Seneke seyth a good worde douteles
He seyth he can no deference fynde
By twyxte aman that ys owte of hys moynde
As a man that ys dronkelewe
But that woodnesse ys fallen in a schrewe
ꝐPer/Parseuereth lenger than doth dronkenesse
O glotenye full of cursednesse
O cause firste of oure confusioun
Originall of oure dampnacion
Tylle cryste hadde bouȝt vs with hys blood aȝen
Lo how dere schortely forto seyn
A bouȝt was the cursed vilenye
Corrupte was all thys worlde thouroȝ glotenye
Adᵃm oure fadir and hys wyf also
Fro paradys to laboure and to woo
Were dryuen in that wyse hit ys no drede
For whyles that adam fasted as y rede
He was in paradys and whan that he
Ete of the fruyte defended on the tre
Anon he was out caste to woo and to peyne
O glotenye on the well owte vs pleyne
O wyste a man how many maladyes
Folweth of excesse and of glotenyes
He wolde ben the more mesurable
Of hys dyot syttynge at hys table
Allas the schorte throte the tender mouthe
Maketh that Este and weste northe and southe
In erthe in eyre in water men to synke
To geton a gloton deynte mete and drynke
Of thys mater o poule well canste thow trete
Mete onto wombe and wombe eke vnto mete
Schall god distroy bothe as poule seythe
Allas a foule thynge hit ys by my faythe
To say thys worde and fouler ys the dede
When men so drynketh of the whyte and rede
That of hys throte he maketh hys preue
Thoruȝ thylke cursed suꝑper/parfluyte ¶
The apostel seyth wepynge full pytously
The walken mony of whyche tolde haue I
I sey hit now wepynge with petous voys
Ther ben enymyes of crystes croys
Of whyche the ende ys deth wombe ys here god
O wombe o bely o stynkynge codde
Fulfulled of donge and of corrupcioıı̄un
At eyther ende of the foule ys the sesoıı̄un
How greet coste and labour ys to fynde
These cokes how they stampe streyne and grynde
And turne substaunce into accident
To fulfulle all thy lycours talent .
Oute of the harde bones knokke they
The mary for they caste hit not a wey
That may goo thoruȝ the golet saf and soote
Of spycerye of leues barke and roote
Schal ben hys saws y maad by delyte
