But certes he that haunteth suche delyces
Is ded whyles that he lyueth into vices
A lechours thynge ys wyn and dronkenesse
Hit ys full of stryuynge and of wrecchednesse
O dronken man disfugured in thy face
Foule ys thy breth foule art thow to enbrace
And thoruȝ thy dronken nose sowneth the soun
As thou seydest ay sampson sampson .
And ȝit god wot sampsoıı̄un dronke neuer no wyne
Thow fallest euer as a dronkēm swyne
Thy tonge ys loste and all thy honeste cure
For dronkenesse ys verry sepulture
Of mannes wyll and hys discrecioıı̄un
In whom thath drynke hath dıı̄unacōmn
He can no councell kepe hit ys no drede
Now kepe ȝow fro the whyte and fro the rede
Namly fro the whyte wyn of leepe
That ys to selle in fyschstret and in cheep
Thys wyn of spayne crepeth subtelly
In other wynes growynge fasteby
Of whyche ryseth suche fumosyte
That whan a man hath dronken a drauȝt or thre ¶
And weneth that he be at hom in chepe
Than ys he in spayne ryȝt at the toun of leep
Nouȝt at rochell ne at bordews toun
And than woll they sey sampsoıı̄un sampsoıı̄un
But herkeneth lordynges o word y ȝow pray
That all the souereyn actis dar y sey
Of victoris in olde testament
That thoruȝ verry god that ys omīmpotent
Were don in abstinence and in prayer
Loketh the bible and ther ȝe may hit leer
Loketh attyla the greet conquerour
Dide in hys sleep with schame and dishonoure
Bledynge at hys nose in dronkenesse
A capteyne scholde lyue in sobirnesse
And ouer all these avyse ȝow ryȝt well
What was cōmmaunded vnto lamuell
Not samuell but lamuell sey I
Redeth the bible and fyndeth hit expssely
Of wyn ȝeuynge of hem that ben iustice
No more at þys for hit may suffice
And now that y haue spoken of glotenye
Now woll y defende ȝow hasardrye
Hasarde ys ferry modir of lesynges
And of disceyt cursed forswerynges
Blaspheme of cryste manslauter and waste also
Of batayle and tyme and ferthermo
Hit ys repreef and contrary to honoure
Forto beholde a cōmmune hasardoure
And eueuer the heyȝer he ys of estaat
The more he ys holden desolat
If that a prynce vse hasardry
In alle gouernaunce and pollicye
He ys as by cōmmune oppinnioun
Hold the lasse in reputacōmn
Styllebon that was holde a wyse bassatour
Was sente in to corynthe with greet honour
Fro calidoyne to make hem alyaunce
And whanne he cam happed thys chaunce
That all the grettest that were of that londe
Pleynge at the hasarde he hēm fonde ¶
For whyche as sone as hit myȝt be
He stale hym hom to hys contre
And seyde there y wolde not lese my name
I wolde not take on me so greet defaute
Forto allye ȝow to non hasardors
Sendeth other wyser enbassators
For by my trouthe me were leuer dye
Than y scholde ȝow to hasardors allye .
For ȝe that ben so gloryous in honours
Schall not allye ȝow with hasardours
As my wyll ne as by my trete
These wyse phylsophres þus seyde
Loke eke that the kynge demetrius
The kynge of partes as the booke seyth thus
Sente hym a peyre dyse of golde in scorne
For he hadde vsed hasardrye ther byforne
For whyche he helde hys glorye and hys renoun
For no value of reputacōmun
Lordes myȝt fynde other maner pleye
Honest y nowȝ to dryue the day a weye
Now woll y speke of othes false and greete
A worde or two as other bokes entrete
Greet swerynge ys a thynge abhominable
And false swerynge ys a thynge reprouable
The hyȝ god forbad swerynge at all
Witnesse of mathew but in speciall
Of swerynge the holy ieremye
Thow schalt swere soth thyne othes and not lye
And swere in doom and eke in rytwesnesse
But ydell swerynge ys a cursednesse
By holde and se that in the firste table
Of hyȝ godes hestes honourable
How that two hestes of hym ys þus
Take not my tale in ydelnesse a mys
Lo he rather for bedeth suche swerynge
Thenne homycide or eny other thynge
I sey as thus by order hit standeth
Thys knoweth that thys hestes vndirstondeth
How that the scdēm heste of god ys that
And furthermore y woll the telle al plat ¶
That veinaunce schall not parte fro hys hous
That of hys hothes ys so outragous
By godes precious hert and hys nayles
And by hys blood that ys in hayles
Seuene ys my chaunce and hys fyue and thre
By godes armes yf thouȝ falsely pleye me
Thys dagger schall thoruȝ thyne herte goo
This fruyt cometh of thilke bones two
Forswerynge yre falsnesse homicide
Now for the loue of cryste that for vs deyde
Leueth ȝoure othes bothe greet and smale
For y schall telle ȝow a meruelous tale
These ryottours of whyche y telle
Longe erste or prime ronge eny belle
Were sterte in a tauerne to drynge
And as they sat they herde a belle clynke
Byforne a cors was brouȝt to hys graue
That on of hem gan calle to hys knaue
Go bet qd he and aske redly
What cors ys that that passeth forth by
And loke that thouȝ reporte hys name well
Sir qd he hit nedeth neuer a deel
Hit was me tolde er we came her to houres
He was parde an olde felawe of ȝoures
All sodeynly was he slayn to nyȝte
For dronken as he sat in hys benche vp ryȝt
Ther com a preuey theef mēm calleth deth
That in hys contrey all peple sleeth
And with hys speer he smot hys herte a two
And wente hys way with out wordes mo
He hath a thousand slayn thys pestilence
And mayster er ȝe come in hys presence
Me thenketh that hit were necessarye
Forto be waar of suche an aduersarye
Beth redy forto mete hym euer more
Thus tauȝte me my dame y sey no more
By seynt mary seyde thys tauerner
The chylde seyth soth for he hath slayne thys ȝere
Hens ouer a myle with ynne a gret village
Bothe man and wōmman chylde and page ¶
I trow hys habitacion be ther
To ben avysed greet wysdom hit wer
Or that he dude a man dishonoure
Ȝe godes armes qd thys ryatoure
Is hit such perell with hym forto mete
I schall hym seche by style and by strete
I make a vowȝ by godes dyne bones
Herkeneth felawes we thre be all ones
Lette eche of vs holde vp hys hondes to other
And eche of vs by come others brother
And we woll sle thys false traytour deth
He schall be slayn that so many sleth
By godes dyngnete er hit be nyȝte
To geder han these thre here hertes plyȝte
To lyue and to dye eche of hem with other
As thouȝ he were hys owne brother
And vp they sterten and dronken in thys rage
And forth they gon toward that viage
Of whyche the tauerner hath spoke by fore
And many a gryslyche oth þer han they swore
And crystes blessed body they to rent
That deth schall be ded yf that we may hym hent
When they haue gon not fully a myle
Ryȝt as they wolde haue troden ouer a style
An olde and pore man hem mette
Thys olde man full mekely hem grette
And seyde thus now lordes god ȝow see
The prowdest of these ryottes thre
Answered aȝen what cherle with harde grace
Why art thou all for wrapped saue thy face
Why leuest thouȝ so longe in so greet age
Thys olde man gan loke in hys vysage
And seyde thus y can not fynde
A mām thouȝ y walked in to Inde
Nether in cete ne in no vyllage
That woll chaungēm hys ȝouthe for myn age
And ther for mot y haue myn age stylle
As longe tyme as hit ys godes wylle
Ne deth allas nell not haue my lyf
Thys walke y lyke a resteles caytyf ¶
And on the grounde whyche ys my moder gate
I knocke with my staf erly and late
And say leue moder let me In
Lo how y wanysch fleysch blood and skyn
Allas whan schall my bones ben at reste
Moder with ȝow wolde y chaunge my cheste
That in my chamber longe tyme hath be
Ȝe for an here cloute to wrappe me
But ȝit to me scho woll not do that grace
For whyche fulwelked ys my face
But sires to ȝow hit ys no curtasye
To speke vnto an olde man vylenye
But he trespace in worde or elles in dede
In holy wryt ȝe may ȝoure self well rede
Aȝenst an olde man hoor vppon hys heed
Ȝe schull a ryse ther for y ȝeue ȝow rede
Ne doth vn to an olde man harme as nouȝ
No more than ȝe wolde a man ded ȝowȝ
In age yf that ȝe so longe a byde
And god be with ȝow whether ȝe goo or ryde
I moot goo theder as y haue to goo
Nay olde chirle by god thouȝ schalt not so
Sayde these other hasarders a non
Thou partest not so lyȝtly be seynt iohn
Thou spak ryȝt now of thilke traytoᵘur deth
That in thys contre alle oure frendes sleth
Haue here my trouthe as thouȝ art hys aspye
Telle where he ys or elles thouȝ schalt dye
By god and by the holy sacrement
For soth thou art of hys assent
To sle vs ȝonge folke thow false theef
Now syres yf hit be to ȝow so leef
To fynde deth turne vp thys croked way
For in that groue y lefte hym by my fay
Vnder a tre and ther he woll a byde
Ne for ȝoure boste he nell hym nothynge hyȝde
Se ȝe that ook ryȝt ther ȝe schull hym fynde
God saue ȝow that bouȝt a ȝen mankynde
And ȝowȝ a mende thus seyde thys olde man
And euery of these ryottours ran . ¶
Tyll they come to the tre and there they founde
Floreyns of golde fyne y coyned rownde
Well nyȝ a seuen buschells as hem thouȝt
No lenger than after deth they souȝte
But eche of hem so glad was of that syȝte
For that the floreyns so fayre ben and so bryȝte
Than doun they sette by the precious horde
The worste of hem he spake the firste worde
Betheren qd he take hede what y saye
My wit ys greet thouȝ y borde and pleye
Thys tresoure hath fortune to vs ȝeuen
In mirthe and iolite oure lyf to lyuen
And lyȝtely as hit cometh so woll we spende
By godes precious hert who wende
To day that we scholde haue so fayre a grace
But myȝht this golde be caryed fro thys place
Hoom in to myn hous or elles into ȝoures
For well y wot that alle the golde ys oures
Than were we in hyȝ felicite
But trewly by day hit may not be
Men woll seyn that we were theues stronge
And for oure owne tresore don vs honge
As wysely and as slyȝly as hit myȝte
Thys tresour moste y caryed be by nyȝte
Wherfore y rede let loke amonge vs all
To drawe lot and se where the cutte woll falle
He that hath the cutte with herte blythe
Schall renne to towne and that full swythe
To brynge vs breed and drynge ful preuely
And two of vs chall kepen sobtelly
Thys tresour well and yf he wyl not tarye
When hit ys nyȝt we woll thys tresour carye
By on assent where vs luste beste
That on of hem brouȝte gras in hys feste
And bad hem drawe and loke on whom hit wolde falle
And hit fell on the ȝongest of hem alle
And forthe towarde the toune he wente anon
And also sone as he was goon
That on of hem spake vnto that other
Thow woste well thow art myn owne sworne brother ¶
Thy profite woll y telle the a non
Thow woste well that oure felawe ys goon
And here ys golde that ryȝt greet plente
That hyt schall de parted amonge vs thre
But natheles yf that y can schape hit so
That hit departed were amonge vs two
Had y not don a frendes torne to the
That other answered y not how that myȝte be
I wolde wel the golde were oures two
What scholde we do that hit myȝt be so
Schall hit be counsell seyd the firste schrewe
And y schall tellen in wordes fewe
What we schull don and brynge hit a boute
I graunte qd that other owte of doute
That by my trouthe y woll the not breweyen
Now qd the firste thow wost well we be tweyne
And two of vs schall strenger be than on
Loke whenne he ys set and that a non
A ryse as thow thow woldest with hym pleye
And y schall ryuen hym thorowȝ the sydes tweye
Whyles that thow strogleste with hym as in game
And with thy dagger loke thow do the same
And thanne schall all thys gold beparted be
My dere frende by twyxte the and me
Thanne may we bothe oure lustes to fullfulle
And pleye at the dys ryȝt at oure owne wylle
And thus acorded ben the schrewes tweye
To sle the thrydde as ȝe herde me seye
Thys ȝongest whyche that wente to the toune
Ful ofte in hys hert hit rolled vp and doune
The bewte of these floreyns feyre and bryȝte
O lorde qd he yf hit so wer y myȝte
Haue all thys tresour to my self allone
There ys no man that lyueth vndir trone
Of golde that scholde that scholde lyue as mery as I
And at the laste the fende oure enemye
Put in hys thouȝt that he scholde poyson bye
With whyche he myȝt slen hys felaws tweye
For why the fende fonde hym in suche leuynge
That he hadde leue hym to sorow brynge ¶>
For thys was vtterly hys entente
To sclen hem bothe and neuer to repente
And forthe he gooth no lengor wolde he tarye
In to the to the toun vn to apotegarye
And preyde hym that he hym wolde selle
Som poyson that he myȝt hys rattes quelle
And eke there was apolkat in hys hawe
That as he seyde hys capouns hadde y slawe
And seyde he wolde wreke hym yf he myȝte
Of vermyn that destroyed hym by nyȝte
The potegary answered thow schalt haue
A thyge that as god my soule saue
In all thys worlde ther nys no creature
That eteth or drynketh of thys confecture
Nouȝt but the mountans of a corne of whete
That he ne schall hys lyf anon for lete
Ȝe sterue he schall and that in schort whyle
Than thow wolde gon a paas not but a myle
Thys poyson that ys so hard and violente
Thys cursed man hath in hys honde y hente
Thys poyson in a boxe and sethens he ran
In to the nexte streete vnto a man
And borowed hym large botels thre
To hys felawes a ȝen repayreth he
The thrydde kepte clene for hys drynke
For alle the nyȝte he schoop hym to swynke
In caryinge of that golde out of that place
And whan thys ryottour with sory grace
Had Filled with hym hys greet botels thre
To hys felaws a ȝen repayreth he
What nedeth hit to sermon ther of more
For ryȝt as they hadde caste hys deth byfore
Ryȝt so they haue hym slayne at that a non .
And whanne that thys was don than spak that on
Now lette vs sitte and drynke and make vs mery
And afterwarde we wolle hys body bury
And after that hit happed hem ꝑper/parcas
To take a botell ther ynne the poyson was
And drank and ȝaf hys felawe drynge also
Thoruȝ whyche they storuen bothe two ¶
But certes y suppose that avysoun
Wroot neuer in no canoun ne in no fen
Mo wonder sorwes of enpoysenynge
Thus hadde these wrecches to her endynge
Thus ended be these homicides two
And eke thys false enpoysoner also
O cursed synne full of all cursednesse
O traytours homicides o wyckednesse
O glotenye luxurye and hasardrye
Thow blasphemor of cryste with vilanye
And othes greet of vsage and of pruyde
Allas mankynde how may hit be tyde
That to thy creature whyche that the wrouȝt
And with hys precious blood the bouȝte
Thow art so false and so vnkynde allas
Now good mēm god for ȝeue ȝow ȝoure trespas
And kepe ȝow fro the synne of auaryce
Myn holy ꝑper/pardon may ȝow alle varysche
So that ȝe offre nobles or starlynges
Other elles seluer spones broches rynges
Boweth ȝoure heed vnd thys bulle
Cometh vp ȝe wyues offreth ȝoure wylle
Ȝoure name y entre here in my rolle a non
In to the blysse of heuen schull ȝe all goon

Ȝe that woll offren as clene and eke ascleer

So graunte ȝow hys ꝑper/pardoun to resceyue
For that ys beste y woll ȝow not disceyue
But sires o worde for ȝat in my tale
I haue relykes and ꝑper/pardoun in my male
As fayre as eny man in engelonde
Whyche were ȝeue me by the popes honde
If eny of ȝow woll of deuocioun

Cometh forth a non and kneleth her adowne
And ȝe may haue parte of the ꝑper/pardoıı̄un

All newe and Fressch at eủer/rey townes ende ¶ꝑper/par
So that ȝe offren all wey new and newe
Nobles and pans whyche that ben good and trewe
Hit ys greet honour to eueryche that ys her

Ȝe for a grote vnbokell a non thy porse
Nay nay than qd he haue y crystes curse
Let be qd he hit schall not be so thech
Thow woldest make me cusse thyne olde breche
And swere hit were a relyke of a seynt
Thowȝ hit were with thy fondement y peynt
But by the crosse whyche seynt Elene fonde
I wolde y had thy coylons in myn honde
In stede of relikes or seyntewarye
Let cutte hem of and y woll lette hem carye
They scholde be schouēm in an hogges torde
Thys ꝑper/pardoner answered not a worde

Now qd oure hoste y woll no lenger playe

Whenne that he saw that all the peple lowȝ
No more of thys for hit ys ryȝte y nowȝ
Sir ꝑper/pardoner be mery and glad of chere
And ȝe sir oste that bicch to me so dere

(base) Quod oure hoost for thow makest me

(base) Of thy verry lewdnesse

div.l: (base) It is a moral tale vertuous
(base) Al be it toold som tyme in sondry wise

(base) That telleth vs / the peyne of Ihu Crist

div.ab: (base) Here bigynneth Chaucers tale of Melibeus

(base) A yong man whilom called Melibeus myghty and
riche bigat vp on his wif that called was Prudence a
doghter which that called was Sophie

(base) vp on a day bifel that
he for his desport is went in to the feeldes hym to pleye

(base) his
wif and eek his doghter hath he laft inwith his hous of which
the dores weren faste yshette
(base) thre of his olde foos han it espied and setten laddres to the walles of his hous and by wyndowes ben entred

(base) and betten his wif and wounded his doghter with
fyue mortal woundes in
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
fyue sondry places

(base) this is to seyn
in hir feet in hir handes in hir erys in hir nose and in hir
mouth and leften hire for deed and wenten awey

(base) Whan Melibeus retourned was in to his hous and seigh al this meschief he
lyk a mad man rentynge his clothes gan to wepe and crye

(base) Prudence his wyf as ferforth as she dorste bisoughte hym of
his wepyng for to stynte

(base) but nat for thy he gan to crye and
wepen euere lenger the moore

(base) This noble wif Prudence
remembred hire vp on the sentence of Ouyde in his book that
cleped is the remedie of loue wher as he seith

(base) he is a fool
that destourbeth the moder to wepe in the deth of hir child
til she haue wept hir fille as for a certeyn tyme

(base) and thanne
shal man doon his diligence with amyable wordes hire to reconforte and preye hire of hir wepyng for to stynte

(base) for which
reson this noble wyf Prudence suffred hir housbonde for to
wepe and crye as for a certeyn space

(base) and whan she say hir
tyme she seyde hym in this wise Allas my lord quod she
why make ye your self for to be lyk a fool
(base) for sothe it aperteneth nat to a wys man to maken swich a sorwe

(base) yowre
doghter with the grace of god shal warisshe and escape

(base) And al were it so that she right now were deed ye ne oghte nat as
for hir deth youre self to destroye

(base) Senec seith the wise man
shal nat take to greet disconfort for the deth of his children

(base) but
certes he sholde suffren it in pacience as wel as he abideth the
deth of his owene propre perrsone

(base) This Melibeus answerde anon
and seyde What man quod he sholde of his wepyng stynte
that hath so gret a cause for to wepe

(base) Ihus crist oure lord hym
self wepte for the deth of lazarus his freend

(base) Prudence
answerde Certes wel I woot attempree wepynge is no thyng
defended to hym that sorweful is amonges folk in sorwe but
it is rather graunted hym to wepe

(base) The Apostle Poul vn to
the Romayns writeth Man shal reioysse with hem that maken ioye
and wepen with swich folk as wepen

(base) but thogh
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
attempree wepyng be graunted outrageous wepyng certes is defended

(base) Mesure
of wepyng sholde be considered after the loore that techeth vs
Senec

(base) Whan that thy freend is deed quod he lat nat thyne eyen
to moyste ben of terys ne to muche drye al thogh the teerys
come to thyne eyen lat hem nat falle

(base) And whan thou hast
forgoon thy freend do diligence to geten another freend and
this is moore wysdom than for to wepe for thy freend which
that thou hast lorn for ther Inne is no boote

(base) And therfore if ye
gouerne yow by Sapience put awey sorwe out of youre herte

(base) Remembre yow that Ihus Syrak seith A man that is ioyous and
glad in herte it hym conserueth florisshynge in his age but
soothly sorweful herte maketh his bones drye

(base) he seith eek
thus that sorwe in herte sleeth ful many a man

(base) Salomon
seith that right as Moththes in the Shepes flees anoyeth
to the clothes and the smale wormes to the tree right so anoyeth sorwe to the herte

(base) wher fore vs oghte as wel in the deth
of oure children as in the losse of oure goodes temporels haue
pacience

(base) Remembre yow vp on the pacient Iob whan he
hadde lost his children and his temporel substance and in his body
endured and receyued ful many a greuous tribulacion yet seide
he thus
(base) Oure lord quod he hath yeue it me

(base) Oure lord hath biraft it me right so as oure lord
hath wold right so it is doon yblessed be the name of oure
lord

(base) To thise forseyde thynges answerde Melibeus vn to
his wif Prudence Alle thy wordes quod he been sothe and
ther to profitable but trewely myn herte is troubled with this
sorwe so greuously that I noot what to doon

(base) lat calle quod
Prudence thy trewe freendes alle and thy lynage whiche that
ben wise telleth youre cas and herkneth what they seye in conseylynge
and yow gouerne after hir sentence

(base) Salomon seith werk
alle thy thynges by conseil and thow shalt neuere repente

(base) Thanne by the conseil of his wyf Prudence this Melibeus leet
callen a greet congregacioun of folk

(base) as Sirurgiens Phisiciens
olde folk and yonge and somme of hise olde enemys reconsiled as
by hir semblant to his loue and in to his grace

(base) and ther with al ther
coomen somme of hise neghebores that diden hym reuerence moore
for drede than for loue as it happeth ofte

(base) Ther coomen also
ful manye subtile flaterers and wise Aduocatz lerned in the
lawe
(base) And whan this folk togydre assembled weren this Melibeus in sorweful wise shewed hem his cas

(base) and by the manere
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
of his speche it semed that in herte he baar a cruel Ire redy to
doon vengeance vp on his foos and sodeynly desired that the
werre sholde bigynne

(base) but nathelees yet axed he hir conseil
vp on this matere

(base) A Sirurgien by licence and assent of swiche
as were wise vp roos and vn to Melibeus seyde as ye may
heere

(base) Sire quod he as to vs Sirurgiens aperteneth that we
do to euery wight the beste that we kan where as we be withholden
and to oure pacientz that we do no damage

(base) wher fore it
happeth many tyme and ofte that whan twey men han euerich
wounded oother o same Sirurgien heeleth hem bothe

(base) wher
fore vn to oure Art it is nat pertinent to norice werre ne parties
to supporte

(base) but certes as to the warisshynge of youre doghter
al be it so that she perilously be wounded we shullen do so ententif bisynesse fro day to nyght that with the grace of god she
shal be hool and sound as soone as is possible

(base) Almoost right
in the same wise the Phisiciens answerden saue that they
seyden a fewe wordes moore

(base) that right as maladyes
ben cured by hir contraries right so shal man warisshe
werre by vengeance

(base) hise neghebores ful of enuye hise
feyned freendes that semeden reconsiled hise flaterers

(base) maden
semblant of wepyng and empeyred and agregged muchel
of this matere in preisynge gretly Melibe of myght of
power of richesse and of freendes despisynge the power
of hise Aduersaries

(base) and seyden outrely that he anon sholde
wreke hym on hise foos and bigynne werre

(base) Vp roos thanne an Aduocat that was wys by leue and by conseil of othere
that weren wise and seyde

(base) Lordynges the nede for the which
we ben assembled in this place is ful heuy thyng and an
heigh matere

(base) by cause of the wrong and of the wikkednesse that
hath be doon and eek by reson of the grete damages that in tyme
comynge been possible to fallen for the same cause

(base) And ek
by reson of the grete richesse and power of the parties bothe

(base) for
the whiche resons it were a ful greet peril to erren in this matere

(base) Wher fore Melibeus this is oure sentence we conseile
yow abouen alle thyng that right anon thow do diligence in
kepynge of thy propre persone in swich a wise that thow ne wante noon espye ne wacche thy body for to saue

(base) And after that
we conseille that in thyn hous thow sette suffisant garnyson so that they may as wel thy body as thyn hous defende

(base) But certes for to moeue werre ne sodeynly for to doon
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
vengeance we may nat deme in so litel tyme that it were
profitable
(base) wher fore we axen leyser and espace to haue deliberacioun in this cas to deme

(base) for the commune prouerbe seyth
this he that soone demeth soone shal repente

(base) And eek men
seyn that thilke Iuge is wys that soone vnderstondeth a matere and Iuggeth by leyser

(base) for al be it so that al taryyng be
anoyful algates it is nat to repreue in yeuyng of Iuggement ne in vengeance takyng whan it is suffisant and
resonable

(base) and that shewed oure lord Ihus crist by ensample for whan that the womman that was taken in auoutrye
was broght in his presence to knowen what sholde be doon
with hir persone al be it that he wiste wel hym self what
that he wolde answere yet ne wolde he nat answere sodeynly but he wolde haue deliberacioun and in the ground he
wroot twies

(base) and bythise causes we axen deliberacion
and we shul thanne by the grace of god conseille thee thyng
that shal be profitable

(base) Vp stirten thanne the yonge folk
atones and the mooste partie of that compaignye han scorned this olde wise man and bigonnen to make noyse and
seyden that

(base) right so as whil that Iren is hoot men sholde smyte right so sholde men wreken hir wronges
whil that they been fresshe and newe and with loud voys
they criden werre werre

(base) vp roos tho oon of thise olde
wise and with his hand made contenance that men sholde
holden hem stille and yeuen hym audience

(base) Lordynges quod he ther is ful many a man that crieth werre
werre that woot ful litel what werre amounteth

(base) Werre at his bigynnyng hath so greet an entree and so large
that euery wight may entre whan hym liketh and lightly fynde werre

(base) But certes what ende that ther of shal falle it
is noght light to knowe

(base) for soothly whan that werre is ones
bigonne ther is ful many a child vnborn of his moder
that shal sterue yong by cause of thilke werre or ellis lyue in
sorwe and dye in wrecchednesse

(base) and ther fore er that any werre
be bigonne men moste haue gret conseil and gret deliberacioun

(base) And whan this olde man wende to enforcen his tale by resons
wel neigh all atones
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
bigonne they to rise for to breken his tale and beden hym ful ofte hise wordes for to abregge

(base) for sothly he that precheth to hem that listen nat heren hise wordes hys
sarmon hem anoyeth

(base) For Ihus Syrak seith That Musyk in
wepynge is a noyous thyng This is to seyn As muche auaileth to speken biforn folk to whiche his speche anoyeth as it
is to synge biforn hym that wepeth

(base) And whan this wise man
say that hym wanted audience al shamefast he sette hym doun
agayn

(base) For Salomon seith ther as thow ne mayst haue non
audience enforce thee nat to speke

(base) I se wel quod this wise
man that the come prouerbe is sooth that good conseil wanteth
whan it is moost nede

(base) yet hadde this Melibeus in his conseil many folk that priuely in his ere conseiled hym certeyn
thyng and conseiled hym the contrarie in general audience

(base) Whan Melibeus hadde herd that the gretteste party of his conseil were acorded that he sholde make werre anon he consented
to hir conseilyng and fully affermed hir sentence

(base) Thanne dame Prudence whan that she say how that hyr
housbonde shoope hym for to wreke hym on his foos and to
bigynne werre she in ful humble wise whan she say hir
tyme seyde hym thise wordes

(base) My lord quod she I you
biseche as hertely as I dar and kan ne haste yow nat to
faste and for alle gerdons as yif me audience

(base) For Piers
Alfonce seith who so that dooth to thee outher good or
harm haste thee nat to quiten it for in this wise thy
freend wol abyde and thyn enemy shal the lenger lyue
in drede

(base) The prouerbe seith he hasteth wel that wysly kan
abide and in wikked haste is no profit

(base) This Melibe answerde vn to his wyf Prudence I purpose nat quod he
to werken by thy conseil for many causes and resons
for certes euery wight wolde holde me thanne a fool

(base) this is to seyn If I for thy conseilyng wolde chaunge
thynges that ben ordeyned and affermed by so manye wise

(base) Secoundly I seye that alle wommen ben wikke and noon good of hem alle
for of a thousand men seith Salomon I foond o good man but
certes of alle wommen good womman foond I neuere

(base) And also certes
if I gouerned me by thy conseil it sholde seme that I hadde yeue
to thee ouer me the maistrie and
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
goddes forbode that it so were

(base) For Ihus Syrak seith that if the wyf haue maistrie she is
contrarious to hir housbonde

(base) And Salomon seith Neuere
in thy lyf to thy wyf ne to thy child ne to thy freend ne yif
no power ouer thy self For bettre it were that thy children
axen of thy persone thynges that hem nedeth than thow see
thy self in the handes of thy children

(base) And also if I wolde
werke by thy conseilyng certes my conseil moste som tyme be
secree til it were tyme that it moste be knowe and this ne
may nat be

(base) Whan Dame Prudence ful debonairly and with
gret pacience hadde herd al that hir housbonde liked for to
seye thanne axed she of hym licence for to speke and
seyde in this wise

(base) My lord quod she as to youre firste
reson certes it may lightly been answered for I seye that it is
no folie to chaunge conseil whan the thyng is chaunged
or ellis whan the thyng semeth oother weys than it was
biforn

(base) And moore ouer I seye that thogh that ye han sworn
and bihight to perfourne youre emprise and nathelees ye weyue
to perfourne thilke same emprise by iuste cause men sholde nat seyn therfore that ye were a lyere ne forsworn

(base) for
the book seith that the wise man maketh no lesyng whan
he turneth his corage to the bettre

(base) And al be it so that youre
emprise be establissed and ordeyned by gret multitude of folk
yet thar ye nat accomplice thilke same ordinance but yow
like

(base) for the trouthe of thynges and the profit ben rather founde
in fewe folk that ben wise and ful of reson than by gret multitude of folk ther euery man crieth and clatereth what that hym
liketh soothly swich multitude is nat honeste

(base) And to the
Seconde resoun where as ye seyn that alle wommen ben wikke
Saue youre grace certes ye despise alle wommen in this wyse
and he that al despiseth al displeseth as seith the book

(base) and
Senec seith that who so wole haue Sapience shal no man
dispreise but he shal gladly teche the science that he kan with
oute presumpcion or pride

(base) and swiche thynges as he noght
ne kan he shal nat ben ashamed to lerne hem and enquere
of lasse folk than hym self

(base) And sire that ther hath be ful many
a good womman may lightly be preued

(base) for certes sire oure lord
Ihus crist wolde neuere han descended to be born of a womman
if alle wommen hadde be wikke

(base) And after that for the grete
bountee that is in wommen oure lord Ihus crist whan he
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
was risen
fro deth to lyf appered rather to a womman than to his apostles

(base) And though that Salomon seith that he ne foond neuere
womman good it folweth nat therfore that alle wommen
ben wikke

(base) for thogh that he ne foond no good womman certes
many another man hath founde many a womman ful good
and trewe

(base) Or ellis parauenture the entente of Salomon was
this that as in souereyn bountee he foond no womman

(base) this is
to seyn that ther is no wight that hath souereyn bountee saue
god allone as he hym self recordeth in his Euangelie

(base) for
ther nys no creature so good that hym ne wanteth som what
of the perfeccioun of god that is his makere

(base) Youre thridde reson is this ye seyn that if ye gouerne yow by my conseil it
sholde seme that ye hadde yeue me the maistrie and the lordshipe ouer youre persone

(base) Sire sauf youre grace it is nat so
for if so were that no man sholde be conseiled but oonly of
hem that hadde lordshipe and maistrie of his persone men wolde nat ben conseiled so ofte

(base) for soothly thilke man that axeth
conseil of a purpos yet hath he free choys wheither he
wole werke by that conseil or noon

(base) And as to youre ferthe
reson ther ye seyn that the Ianglerye of wommen kan hide
thynges that they woot nat as who seith that a womman
kan nat hide that that she woot

(base) Sire thise wordes been
vnderstonde of wommen that ben Iangleresses and wikked

(base) of
whiche wommen men seyn that thre thynges dryuen a man
out of his hous that is to seyn Smoke droppyng of
reyn and wikked wyues

(base) and of swiche wommen seith Salomon that it were bettre dwellen in desert than with a womman
that is riotous
(base) and sire by youre leue that am nat I

div.l:
Here endeþ þe tale of Mellibe
And begynneth the tale of þe Frankleyn
IN fayth squyer thow hast the well y quytte
And gentelly I preise well thy wytte
Qd the frankeleyne considerynge thy ȝouthe
So felyngely thow spekest sir y alouthe
As to my dom ther ys non that ys here
Of eloquence that schal be thy pere
If that thow leue god ȝeue the good chaunce
And in vertue sende the continuaunce
For of thy speche y haue gret deynte
I haue a sone and by the trinite
I hadde leuer then twenty pounde worth londe
Thouȝ ryȝt now hit were fallēm in myn honde ¶
He were amām of suche discressioıı̄un
As that ȝe ben fy on possessioun
But yf a man be vertues with all
I haue my sone snybbed and ȝit y schall
For he to vertu lysteþ not to endende
But forto pley at dys and forto spende
And lese al that he hath ys hys vsage
And he had leuer talken with a page
Then to comune with eny gentell wyȝt
Where hemyȝt lerne gentelnesse a ryȝte
Straw for ȝoure gentelnesse qd oure oste
What frankeleyne qd he well thouȝ woste
That echone of ȝow moste tellēm at þe leste
A tale or two or breken hys heste
That knowe y well sire qd þe frankeleyne
I prey ȝow haueth not me me in disdeyne
Thouȝ y to thys man speke a worde or two
Telle on thy tale with oute wordes mo
Gladly sir oste qd he y woll obeye
Vnto ȝoure will nouȝ herkeneth what y seye
I woll ȝow not contrarye in no wyse
As ferre as that my wittes woll suffise
I pray to god that hit may plessen ȝow
Thenne wot y well þat hit ys good y nowȝ

Here endeth þe prologe / / And begynneþ the tale of the
Frankleyn

(base) To loue me best god woot ye seyden so
(base) Al be that I vnworthy am ther to
(base) Madame I speke it for the honour of yow
(base) Moore than to saue myn hertes lyf right now
(base) I haue do so as ye comaunded me
(base) And if ye vouche sauf ye may go se
(base) Dooth as yow list haue youre biheste in mynde
(base) For quyk or deed right ther ye shal me fynde
(base) In yow lyth al to do me lyue or deye
(base) But wel I woot the Rokkes been aweye
(base) He taketh his leue and she astoned stood
(base) In al hir face nas a drope of blood
(base) She wende neuere haue come in swich a trappe
(base) Allas quod she that euere this sholde happe
(base) For wende I neuere by possibilitee
(base) That swich a Monstre or merueille myghte be
(base) And hom she gooth a sorweful creature
(base) It is agayns the proces of nature
(base) For verray feere vnnethe may she go
(base) She wepeth wayleth al a day or two
(base) And swowneth that it routhe was to se
(base) But why it was to no wight tolde she
(base) For out of towne was goon Arueragus
(base) But to hirself she spak and seyde thus
(base) In hir compleinte as ye shal after heere
(base) With face pale and with ful sorweful cheere
(base) Allas quod she on thee Fortune I pleyne
(base) That vnwar wrapped hast me in thy cheyne
(base) For which to escape woot I no socour
(base) Saue oonly deeth or deshonour
(base) Oon of thise two bihoueth me to chese
(base) But nathelees yet haue I leuere to lese
(base) My lyf than of my body to haue a shame
(base) Or knowen myseluen fals or lese my name
(base) And with my deeth I may be quyt ywis
(base) Hath ther nat many a noble wyf er this
(base) And many a mayde yslayn hirself allas
(base) Rather than with hir body doon trespas
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Yis certes lo thise stories beren witnesse
(base) Whan thirty tirauntz ful of cursednesse
(base) Hadde slayn Phidon in Atthenes atte feste
(base) They comaunded his doghtren for to areste
(base) And bryngen hem biforn hem in despit
(base) Al naked to fulfille hir foul delit
(base) And in hir fadres blood they made hem daunce
(base) Vpon the pauement god yeue hem meschaunce
(base) For which thise woful maydens ful of drede
(base) Rather than they wolde lese hir maydenhede
(base) They pryuely been stirt in to a welle
(base) And dreynte hemseluen as the bokes telle
(base) They of Mecene leete enquere and seke
(base) Of Lacedomye fifty maydens eke
(base) On whiche they wolden doon hir lecherye
(base) But was ther noon of al that compaignye
(base) That she nas slayn and with a good entente
(base) Chees rather for to dye than assente
(base) To been oppressed of hir maydenhede
(base) Why sholde I thanne to dye been in drede
(base) Loo eek the tiraunt Aristoclides
(base) That loued a mayden highte Stymphalides
(base) Whan that hir fader slayn was on a nyght
(base) Vnto Dianes temple gooth she right
(base) And hente the ymage in hir handes two
(base) Fro which ymage wolde she neuere go
(base) No wight ne myghte hir handes of it arace
(base) Til she was slayn right in the selue place
(base) Now sith that maydens hadden swich despit
(base) To been defouled with mannes foul delit
(base) Wel oghte a wyf rather hirseluen sle
(base) Than be defouled as it thynketh me
(base) What shal I seyn of hasdrubales wyf
(base) That at Cartage birafte hirself hir lyf
(base) For whan she saw that Romayns wan the town
(base) She took hir children alle and skipte adown
(base) In to the fyr and chees rather to dye
(base) Thenne be defouled or hadde velenye
(base) Hath nat Lucresse yslayn hirself allas
(base) At Rome whan she oppressed was

div.ab:
(base) soothly that oon ne may nat ben with outhen that
oother

(base) and truste wel that in the name of thy neighebore thow
shalt vnderstonde the name of thy brother for certes alle we
haue o fader flesshly and o moder that is to seyn Adam and
Eue and eek o fader Spirituel that is god of heuene

(base) thy
neighebore artow holden for to loue and wilne hym alle goodnesse and therfore seith god loue thy neighebore as thy self
that is to seyn to sauacion bothe of lyf and soule

(base) and moore
ouer thow shalt loue hym in word and benygne amonestynge
and chastisynge and conforte hym in hise anoyes and preye for hym
with al thyn herte

(base) And in dede thow shalt loue hym in swich
wise that thow shalt doon to hym in charitee as thow woldest
that were doon to thyn owene persone

(base) and therfore thow ne shalt
doon hym no damage in wikked word ne harm in his body
ne in his catel ne in his soule by entisynge of wikked ensample

(base) Thow shalt nat eek desiren his wyf ne none of hyse
thynges Vnderstoond eek that in the name of neighebore is
comprehended his enemy

(base) certes man shal loue his enemy for the
comandement of god and soothly thy freend shaltow loue
in god

(base) I seye thyn enemy shaltow loue for goddes sake by
his comandement for if it were resoun that man sholde hate
his enemy for sothe god nolde nat receyuen vs to his loue
that ben hise enemys

(base) Agayns iij manere of wronges that
his enemy dooth to hym he shal doon iij thynges as thus

(base) Agayns hate and rancour of herte he shal loue hym in herte
Agayns chidynge and wikked wordes he shal preye for his enemy Agayns the wikked dede of his enemy he shal doon
hym bountee

(base) for crist seith loueth youre enemys and preieth
for hem that speke yow harm and eek for hem that yow chacen
and pursuen and dooth bountee to hem that yow haten lo
thus comandeth vs oure lord Ihesu crist to do to oure enemys

(base) for soothly nature dryueth vs to louen oure frendes and parfey
oure enemys han moore nede to loue than oure frendes and
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
they that moore nede haue certes to hem shal men doon goodnesse

(base) and certes in thilke dede haue we remembraunce of the loue
of Ihesu crist that deyde for hise enemys

(base) and in as muche as
thilke loue is the moore greuous to perfourne so muche is the
moore gret the merite and therfore the louynge of of oure
enemy hath confounded the venym of the deuel

(base) for right
as the deuel is desconfited by humylitee right so is he wownded to the deth by the loue of oure enemy

(base) certes thanne is
loue the medicyne that chaceth out the venym of enuye fro
mannes herte
(base) ¶ Sequitur de Ira
(base) The speces of this pas shullen ben moore largely declared in hire chapitres folwynge
(base) Ira

(base) After Enuye wol I discryuen the synne of Ire for
soothly who so that hath enuye vp on his neighebore
anon he wole communely fynde hym matere of wrathathe in word or in
dede agayns hym to whom he hath enuye

(base) and as wel comth Ire of pride
as of enuye for soothly he that is proud or enuyous is lightly wroth

(base) This synne of Ire after the discryuyng of Seint Augustyn is
wikked wil to ben auenged by word or by dede

(base) Ire after the
philosophre is the feruent blood of man yquyked in his herte
thurgh which he wole harm to hym that he hateth

(base) for certes the
herte of man by eschawfynge and moeuynge of his blood wexeth
so trouble that he is out of alle Iugement of resoun

(base) But ye shal
vnderstonde that Ire is in two maneres that oon of hem is good and
that oother is wikke

(base) the goode Ire is by Ialowsie of goodnesse
thurgh which a man is wrooth with wikkednesse and agayns wikkednesse and therfore seith a wys that Ire is bet than pley

(base) this Ire
is with debonairetee and it is wroth with oute bitternesse nat wroth
agayns the man but wroth with the mysdede of the man as seith
the prophete Dauid Irascimini et nolite peccare

(base) Now vnderstondeth that wikked Ire is in ijmaneres that is to seyn sodeyn Ire
or hastif Ire with oute auysement and consentynge of his reson

(base) the Menyng and the sens of this is that the reson of a man
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
ne
consente nat to thilke sodeyn Ire and thanne is it venyal

(base) Another Ire is ful wikked that comth of felonye of herte auysed
and cast bifore with wikked wil to do vengeaunce and ther tohis resoun
consenteth and soothly this is dedly synne

(base) this Ire is so displesant to god that it troubleth his hous and chaceth the holy goost
out of mannes soule and wasteth and destroyeth the liknesse of
god that is to seyn the vertu that is in mannes soule

(base) and put in
hym the liknesse of the deuel and bynymeth the man fro god that
is his rightful lord

(base) this Ire is a ful gret plesaunce to the
deuel for it is the deueles forneys that is eschawfed with the
fyr of helle

(base) for certes right so as fyr is moore myghty to
destroye erthely thynges than another Element right so Ire
is myghty to destroye alle spirituel thynges

(base) Looke how that
fyr of smale gleedes that ben almoost dede vnder the Asshen
wolen quyke agayn whan they ben touched with brym ston
right so Ire wole euere mo quyke agayn whan it is touched
by the pryde that is couered in mannes herte

(base) for certes fyr ne may
nat come out of no thyng but if it were first in the same
thyng naturelly as fyr is drawen out of flyntes with
Steel

(base) and right so as pryde is ofte tyme matere of Ire right
so is rancour norice and kepere of Ire

(base) Ther is a manere tree
as seith sein ysidre that
whan men maken fir of thilke tree and couere the coles of it with Asshen
soothly the fir of it wol lasten al a yeer or moore

(base) And right so fareth
it of rancour whan it is ones conceyued in the hertes of som men
certein it wol lasten perauenture from oon Estre day vn to another Estre
day and moore

(base) but certes thilke man is ful fer fro the mercy of god in
thilke while

(base) In this forseyde deueles fourneys ther forgen iij shrewes Pride that ay bloweth and encreesseth the fir by chidynge and wikked
wordes

(base) Thanne stant Enuye and holdeth the hoote Iren vpon the hte
of man with a peire of longe toonges of long rancour

(base) And thanne
stant the synne of contumelie or strif and cheeste and batereth and
forgeth by vileyns repreuynges

(base) Certes this cursed synne anoyeth
bothe to the man hym self and eek to his neighebore
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
For soothly almoost
al the harm that any man dooth to his neighebore comth of wratthe

(base) for certes
outrageous wratthe dooth al that euere the deuel hym comaundeth for he ne
spareth neither crist ne his sweete mooder

(base) And in his outrageous anger and
Ire allas allas ful many oon at that tyme feeleth in his herte ful wikkedly
bothe of crist and of alle hise halwes
(base) but spekyth and sklaundryth his neyghbour

(base) Is nat this a cursed vice yis certes
Allas it bynymeth from man his wit and his resoun and al his debonaire
lif espiritueel that sholde kepen his soule

(base) Certes it bynymeth eek
goddes due lordshipe and that is mannes soule and the loue of hise
neighebores It stryueth eek alday agayn trouthe It reueth hym the quiete of his herte and subuerteth his soule

(base) Of Ire comen thise stynkynge
engendrures First hate that is oold wratthe discord thurgh which a
man forsaketh his olde freend ful longe

(base) And thanne cometh werre and
euery manere of wrong that man dooth to his neighebore in body or in catel

(base) Of this cursed synne of Ire cometh eek manslaughtre And vnderstonde
wel that homycide that is manslaughtre is in diuerse wise Som manere
of homycide is spiritueel and som is bodily

(base) Spiritueel manslaughtre
is in vjthynges First by hate as Seint Iohn seith he that hateth his
brother is homycide

(base) Homycide is eek by bakbitynge of whiche bakbiteres seith Salomon that they han two swerdes with whiche the sleen hir
neighebores For soothly as wikke is to bynyme his good name as his lyf

(base) Homycide is eek in yeuynge of wikked conseil by fraude as for to yeuen
conseil to areysen wrongful custumes and taillages

(base) of whiche seith
Salomon Leou rorynge and Bere hongry been like to the crueel lordshipes in withholdynge or abreggynge of the shepe or the hyre or of the wages of seruauntz or elles in vsures or in withdrawynge of the almesse of
poure folk

(base) For which the wise man seith Fedeth hym that almoost dyeth
for honger for soothly but if thow feede hym thou sleest hym and alle
thise been deedly synnes

(base) Bodily manslaughtre
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
is whan thow sleest him
with thy tonge In oother manere as whan thou comandest to sleen a
man or elles yeuest hym conseil to sleen a man

(base) Manslaughtre in dede
is in iiij maneres That oon is by lawe right as a Iustice dampneth hym that is coupable to the deeth but lat the Iustice be war that
he do it rightfully and that he do it nat for delit to spille blood but
for kepynge of rightwisnesse

(base) Another homycide is that is doon
for necessitee as whan o man sleeth another in his defendaunt and that
he ne may noon ootherwise escape from his owene deeth

(base) but certeinly
if he may escape with outen manslaughtre of his Aduersarie and sleeth
hym he dooth synne and he shal bere penance as for deedly synne

(base) Eek if a man by caas or auenture shete an Arwe or caste a stoon with
which he sleeth a man he is homycide

(base) Eek if a wonman by necligence ouerlyeth hir child in hir slepyng it is homycide and deedly
synne
(base) and horrible dedly synnes

(base) Eek whan man destourbeth concepcioun of a child and maketh a womman outher bareyne by drynkynge venenouse herbes thurgh
which she may nat conceyue or sleeth a child by drynkes wilfully
or elles putteth certeine material thynges in hir secree places to slee
the child

(base) or elles dooth vnkyndely synne by which man or wonman shedeth hir nature in manere or in place ther as a child may nat be conceiued or elles if a woman haue conceyued and hurt hir child and sleeth
the child yet it is homycide
(base) What seye we eek of wommen that mordren hir children for drede of worldly shame certes an horrible homicide

(base) Homycide is eek if a man approcheth to a wonman by desir of lecherie thurg
which the child is perissed or elles smyteth a wonman wityngly thurgh
which she leseth hir child Alle thise been homycides and horrible deedly
synnes

(base) Yet comen ther of Ire manye mo synnes as wel in word as
in thoght and in dede as he that arretteth vp on god or blameth god of
thyng of which he is hym self gilty or despiseth god and alle hise halwes as doon thise cursede hasardours in diuerse contrees

(base) This cursed synne doon they whan they feelen
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
in hir hertes ful wikkedly of god and
of hise halwes

(base) Also whan they treten vnreuerently the sacrement of
the Auter thilke synne is so greet that vnnethe may it been releessed
but that the mercy of god passeth alle hise werkes it is so greet and he
so benigne
(base) Thanne comth of Ire attry Angre whan a man is sharply amonested in his shrifte to forleten his synne

(base) thanne wole he be
angry and answeren hokerly and angrily and deffenden or excusen his
synne by vnstedefastnesse of his flessh or elles he dide it for to holde
compaignye with hise felawes or elles he seith the feend enticed hym

(base) or elles he dide it for his youthe or elles his conpleccioun is so corageous that he may nat forbere or elles it is his destinee as he seith vnto a certein age or elles he seith it cometh hym of gentillesse of hise
Auncestres and semblable thynges

(base) Alle this manere of folk so wrappen hem in hir synnes that they ne wol nat deliuere hem self For
soothly no wight that excuseth hym wilfully of his synne may nat
been deliuered of his synne til that he mekely bikNoweth his synne
(base) After this thanne cometh sweryng that is expres agayn the comandement of god and this bifalleth ofte of anger and of Ire

(base) God seith
thow shalt nat take the name of thy lord god in veyn or in ydel Also
oure lord Ihesu crist seith by the word of Seint Mathew

(base) Nolite iura
re omniuo

(base) Ne wol ye nat
swere in alle manere neither by heuene for it is goddes trone ne
by erthe for it is the bench of his feet ne by Ierusalem for it is the
Citee of a greet kyng ne by thyn heed for thou mayst nat make an
heer whit ne blak

(base) but seyeth by youre word ye ye and nay nay
and what that is moore it is of yuel seith crist

(base) For cristes sake
ne swereth nat so synfully in dismembrynge of Crist by soule
herte bones and body For certes it semeth that ye thynke that the
cursede Iewes ne dismembred nat ynough the preciouse persone of crist
but ye dismembre hym moore

(base) And if so be that the lawe compelle
yow to swere thanne rule yow after the lawe of god in youre sweryng as seith Ieremye 4ᵒ capit
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
Thou shalt kepe iij condicions
Thou shalt swere in trouthe in doom and in rightwisnesse

(base) this
is to seyn thou shalt swere sooth for euery lesynge is agayns
Crist For crist is verray trouthe And thynk wel this that euery
greet swerere nat compelled lawefully to swere the wounde
shal nat departe from his hous whil he vseth swich vnleueful sweryng

(base) Thou shalt sweren eek in doom whan thou art
constreyned by thy domesman to witnessen the trouthe

(base) Eek
thow shalt nat swere for enuye ne for fauor ne for meede but for
rightwisnesse and for declaracioun of it to the worship of god and helpyng of thyne euene cristene

(base) And therfore euery man that taketh
goddes name in ydel or falsly swereth with his mouth or elles
taketh on hym the name of crist to be called a cristene man and
lyueth agayns Cristes lyuynge and his techynge alle they taken
goddes name in ydel

(base) Looke eek what seint Peter seith Actuum 4ᵒ
Non est aliud nomen sub celo et cetera Ther nys noon oother name seith seint Peter vnder heuene yeuen to men in which
they mowe be saued that is to seyn but the name of Ihesu crist

(base) Take kepe eek how that the precious name of crist as seith seint
Paul ad Philipenses 2ᵒ In nomine Ihesu et cetera that in the name
of Ihesu euery knee of heuenely creatures or erthely or of helle
sholden bowe for it is so heigh and so worshipful that the cursede feend in helle sholde tremblen to heeren it ynempned

(base) Thanne semeth it that men that sweren so horriblely by his blessed name that they despise hym moore booldely than dide the cursede Iewes or elles the deuel that trembleth whan he heereth his
name

(base) Ow certes sith that sweryng but if it be lawefully doon
is so heighly deffended muche worse is forsweryng falsly and yet
nedelees

(base) What seye we eek of hem that deliten hem in sweryng
and holden it a gentrie or a manly dede to swere grete othes And
what of hem that of verray vsage ne cesse nat to swere grete othes al be the cause nat worth a straw certes it is horrible synne
(base) Swerynge sodeynly with oute auysement is eek a synne

(base) But lat vs go Now
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
to thilke horrible sweryng of Adiuracioun
and coniuracioun as doon thise false Enchauntours or Nigromanens in bacyns ful of water or in a bright swerd in a Cercle or
in a fir or in a shulder boon of a sheep

(base) I kan nat seye but that
they doon cursedly and dampnablely agayns crist and al the
feith of hooly chirche

(base) What seye we of hem that bileeuen in diuynailes as by flight or by noyse of briddes or of beestes or by
sort by Geomancie by dremes by chirkynge of dores or crakkynge of houses by gnawynge of rattes and swich manere
wrecchednesse

(base) certes al this thyng is deffended by god and by
al hooly chirche For which they been acursed til they come to
amendement that on swich filthe setten hir bileeue

(base) Charmes for woundes or maladie of men or of beestes if they taken
any effect it be per auenture that god suffreth it for folk sholden
yeue the moore feith and reuerence to his name

(base) Now wol I
speken of lesynges which generally is fals signyficacioun
of word in entente to deceyuen his euene cristene

(base) Som lesynge is of which ther comth noon auantage to no wight And
som lesynge turneth to the ese and profit of o man and to disese and damage of another man

(base) Another lesynge for to sauen his lyf or his catel comth of delit for to lye in which delit
they wol forge a long tale and peynten it with alle circumstaunces where al the ground of the tale is fals

(base) Som lesynge
comth for he wole sustene his word And som lesynge comth of
reccheleesnesse with outen auisement and semblable thynges

(base) Lat
vs Now touche the vice of flaterynge which ne comth nat gladly
but for drede or for coueitise

(base) Flaterye is generally wrongful
preisynge Flatereres been the deueles norices that norissen hise
children with Milk of losengerie

(base) For sothe Salomon seith that
flaterie is wors than detraccioun for som tyme detraccion maketh an hauteyn man be the moore humble for he dredeth detraccion but certes flaterye that maketh a man to enhauncen his herte
and his contenaunce

(base) Flatereres been the deueles Enchauntours
for the make a man to wene of hym
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
self be lyk that he nys nat
lyk

(base) they been lyk to Iudas that bitraysed a man to sellen hym
to hise enemy that is to the deuel

(base) Flatereres been the deueles
Chapelleyns that syngen euere Placebo

(base) I rekene flarie in the vices of Ire for ofte tyme if o man be wrooth with another thanne
wole he flatere som wight to sustene hym in his querele

(base) Speke we Now of swich cursynge as comth of Irous herte Malisoun
generally may be seyd euery maner power or harm swich cursynge bireueth man fro the regne of god as seith seint Paul

(base) And
ofte tyme swich cursynge wrongfully retorneth agayn to hym that
curseth as a bryd that retorneth agayn to his owene nest

(base) And ouer alle thyng men oghten eschewe to cursen hir children and yeuen to the deuel hir engendrure as ferforth as in hem is certes it
is greet peril and greet synne

(base) Lat vs thanne speken of chidynge
and reproche whiche been ful grete woundes in mannes herte for they
vnsowen the semes of freendshipe in mannes herte

(base) For certes vnnethes may a man pleynly been accorded with hym that hath hym
openly reuyled and repreued in disclaundre This is a ful grisly synne as crist seith in the gospel

(base) And taak kepe Now that he that
repreueth his neighebor outher he repreueth hym by som harm of
peyne that he hath on his body as Mesel croked harlot or by som
synne that he dooth

(base) that he hath ouer his body as mesell Croked
harlot or by som synne that he doth

(base) Now if he repreue hym by harm of peyne
thanne turneth the repreue to Ihesu crist for peyne is sent by the
rightwys sonde of god and by his suffrance be it Meselrie or Maheym
or maladie

in slepynge and this synne cometh ofte to hem that been maydenes
and eek to hem that been corrupt and this synne men clepen Polucioun
that comth in iij maneres Somtyme of langwissynge of body for the
humors been to ranke and habundaunt in the body of man

(base) Somtyme
of infermetee for the fieblesse of the vertu retentif as phisik maketh mencioun somtyme for surfeet of mete and drynke

(base) And somtyme of vileyns thoghtes that been enclosed in mannes mynde whan he gooth to
slepe which may nat been with oute synne for which men moste kepen
hem wisely or elles may men synnen ful greuously

(base) And
somtyme for vyolente thoughtis that ben enclosid in mannys
mynde whan he goth to slepe whiche may not be wyth out synne
For whiche men must kepe hem wysely or ellys may they synne
greuously
(base) Remedium contra peccatum Luxurie

(base) NOw comth the remedie agayns leccherie and that is generally
Chastitee and Continence that restreyneth alle the desordeynee moeuynges that comen of flesshly talentes

(base) And euere the gretter merite
shal he han that moost restreyneth the wikkede eschawfynges of the
ordure of this synne and this is in two maneres that is to seyn chastitee in mariage and chastitee of widwehode

(base) Now shaltow vnderstonde
that matrimoyne is leefful assemblynge of man And of wonman that
